content:
Posted: January 15, 2013
												Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is a continuation of the Supreme Commander formula of giant map and truly insane amounts of units doing battle across ground, land and air. It does have some problems however, especially if you like me prefer single-player.Forged Alliance has no progression of tech unlike the original, you start with everything unlocked and more often than not a base already built and for a single-player experience that is a great offense because it removes half of the gameplay from the equation and often just leaves you with spamming units at the enemy.While many parts of the game has been improved in Forged Alliance the lackluster single-player experience leaves me with a bitter taste and little interest in continuing my adventure and that's a shame because the Supreme Commander formula of scale beyond anything RTS gamers have seen in a long time is something I really enjoyed.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												A must have for anyone interesting in a Real time strategy game, new or experienced.Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is probably the shinest gem out there that still blows all the other next generation RTS games by this day. It has nearly everything that an RTS must have, the necessities and unique features, such as faction diversity, adjacency bonuses, and mod support as well. It may seem complicated at first, but you get used to it pretty fast, as it is easy to learn.The community is still alive and working here, usually hanging on the Forged Alliance Forever lobby mod, which optimizes the game further and adds working multiplayer lobbies, ranked matchmaking, and so forth.Each unit from each faction serves a vital role in your great conquest across the the entire battlefield, lots of diversity into them as well.Resources is a pretty interesting one, unique but sometimes frustrating if you don't know your build orders. I highly recommend this game.

												This game is the single best strategy game i have ever played, if you like fairly complicated start games thenn this game is for you but i do not recommend getting it off Steam  and get it off {LINK REMOVED} for a measly £3.90 or something along hose lines. the sheer amount of units in this game makes it the most diverse RTS game ive ever played, the amount of units and different buildings makes for a sick game. if you are new to startegy games then i don't really recommend this game due to the size of it and how complex it can get if you are playing against people who are actually good at the game. the games on this game can last up to 2 and a half hours. there is a 3rd party app for this game called FAF (Forged Alliance Forever) which is where most of the Forged Alliance community is based but there are still a few people that play the normal version. this game is very easy to run i can tell you this because i get 60fps and my pc is not very good at all. i would give this game a 9/10 and the only reason its not a 10 is because it is not very new player freindly and throws you into a massive battle at the start of the campaign and not telling you really what to do. Brilliant game overall :)

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												An underappreciated real-time strategy game way ahead of it's time. Truly a masterpiece - 10/10I've yet to see another real-time strategy game that captures the scale, and sheer awesomeness of the battles in Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. Battles span across sprawling landscapes, massive seas, and in the air. You play the role of a supreme commander, commanding your army from a giant battle mecha armor called an Armored Command Unit (ACU), a customizable, badass one-man army of it's own, highly capable of both fighting and building structures to support your economy and to produce forces. From this literal war machine, you will be commanding hundreds of units at a time, and if the battles go on too long, you'll gain the technology to produce game-ending experimental super weapons, ranging from massive motherships,  untouchable orbital lasers, sacred assault bots, to experimental resource generators or experimental nuclear missiles capable of wiping out significant portions of the map. Since the scale of the combat is so vast, and the realistic fluidity of unit movement makes precise micromanagement impossible, you will be mostly focused on unit composition and macro-management of resources, expansions, and factories. The economy in this game is income based, so this means you will never need to worry about running out of resources, but you need to make sure you're not overspending your income, or production will slow down significantly. You can also stockpile resources if you have adequate storage.  This means you may, however, overspend if you have a significant amount of resources stockpiled. This allows you to surge production when you need to, to fend off a vicious assault, or to build a high-cost experimental weapon. In short, this is a must play game for RTS fans looking for epic, slower-paced, strategy-heavy combat.P.S. If you have this game, I highly recommend you augment it with the Forged Alliance Forever mod+client. It provides a very active online community, a platform to host games and play online games, and a rebalancing of game mechanics. I use this excusively when playing, this is why my play time recorded on Steam is so low, I actually easily have hundreds of hours in this game.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												Owned the game for a long time, decided to buy it on Steam some time ago, a very good decision!Beautiful graphics, the shield rendering, explosions, and bullet rains all over the place!The stock AI is kinda dumb tough, take the Sorian AI mod, and the game becomes much better, very challenging!Just a shame it's badly programmed... even on top-notch I7's (3610QM & 4700MQ, no extreme overclocked sh**) it causes a pretty heavy load (Full load on 2 cores often), and when playing with a lot of AI's the game can even freeze up. I have no idea how anyone would play this with a 1.8 Ghz processor, which the requirements state.... Probably only possible with a resolution of 320x240.Also the requirements state like "1 GB RAM", well even with 8 GB RAM you still can run into low memory warnings, which is a bug, because there is always 2GB+ RAM still free... it seems this is much more likely to happen when having a resolution of 1920x1080, because I suppose the game has to allocate more memory for the bigger textures.Whenever you get these low memory warnings, at any given moment your game could just crash, it can mess up your desktop. Meaning you have to reboot your computer by force. (Or if you are not the average person, open up the CMD blindly, and kill the process)But with some tools like Core Maximizer and Large Address Aware the game runs a lot better.Multiplayer is very nice in this game, no annoying lag, and there are enough configuration options for all the maps.Maybe i've said some bad things about this game in the review, but it's definitely worth the money! No doubt!!!You will love this game, Skirmish mode rocks.When talking about ratings, I would say this I guess...Gameplay 9/10 No real glitchy behavior, factions all have good units, each with their own unique strenghtsGraphics 8/10 Very good graphics, especially for it's time, turn on Bloom, and the game looks much better, or download shaders. Of course we're not comparing this to games from 2014.Audio 9/10 Nice sound effects, like the artillary cannons, or from experimentalsPerformance 6/10 Like I said, you need a pretty fancy computer to run this game, with ATLEAST medium graphics, and a resolution bigger than 800x600, a 1.8 Ghz CPU and GPU with 128 MB VRAM ain't going to do the job.Use the tools provided by the community to make the game run much smoother!

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												It's a shame that almost no current RTS games could come close to how good this game is. Massively scaled at 2000 unitcap. You would usually expect to see hundreds of units pitting against each other in a single battle. Comes with a huge variety of units\buildings to boot. Ranging from Tech1, 2, 3 and finally experimental. Each faction (out of 4) are completely different from each other, be it units or buildings. You pick the faction that suits your play style the most. It's in depth as there are countless of possible strategies that you can come up with. Be it spamming a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of T1 units to swarm your opponent, overpower them with higher tech, or you could even just turtle all the way to victory via nukes and artillery. You wont expect the 'typical RTS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t' point system where you have 'unlock' certain units\function\blabla. *Ahem* RedAlert3. No, every game is fully fledged, you play the game how you want it to be without lame limitations. And oh yeah, air units here have fuel.There's plenty to talk about how good this game is, but then it would defeat the purpose of actually getting the game and enjoying it first hand. By yourself.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Where to start? Supreme Commander is in one word: MASSIVE. You can set a cap of 8000 units on the battlefield, so if you have a 1v1, each player can have 4000 units. FOUR-F******-THOUSAND. At 8 players (teams don't have to be fair) each player has a thousand troops. I have seen people compare this game to Starcraft with 200 units at the max per player. Some people like the extreme tactics that game has, this game has them too, except on a bigger scale. Let me show you a quick comparisonAirdrops: Starcaft: Drop 16 marines in 2 medivacs.Supreme Commader: Drop 20 units in 1 transport.ArmiesStarcraft: A marine/marauder deathball slaughtering zerglings or a zealot rushSupreme Commander: A 300 strong army supported by experimentals holds off the main force, as battleships and carriers support the army, then on the over side of the map 5 nuclear subs nuke the enemy base as an airdrop composed of 150 units flanks the main force. (And that is on a 1000 units per team)Nukes: (I know that it's only a lesser part of Starcraft, but it is quite big in the end game of Supreme Commander)Starcraft: A Nuke won't destroy the main base building, it's mainly for clearing armies or finishing off basesSupreme Commander: When you usually send nukes, you send 5 or more. Depending on nuke defences the attack might fail but when it hits, it hits. A nuke will wipe a base.DefenceStarcraft: SC is about the offensive and manuevering, you defend to hold the army off as a bigger force flanks.Supreme Commander: If you have ever played Halo Reach, on the desert mission where you need to destroy the AA towers, at the end there is a massive Spire. Imagine that but around the spire there is about 50 gatling guns and AA turrets. Also (most games don't have this) you CAN build WALLS. (I know it's amazing)While I personally like this feature of this game, some peope disagree. There are NO hard counters. (Well yes, the tech 2  UEF flak turret tank will easily  wipe out tech 2 planes and even take on tech 3 planes. And yes, the experimentals are basically hard counters for everything they can target, and the air vs air planes will SLAUGHTER EVERYONE WHO FLIES.) But mostly a tech 3 robot will not have an advantage over a tech 3 tank or vise verca.  And although all the factions look different and have different units, they are mostly the same. The main differences are: some factions unlock different units earlier. eg the Aeon unlock have a tech 1 attack boat. And the experimentals; each faction has 3 or 4 different experimental units.  The graphics are not Starcraft level, but they are still REALLY good.I would reccomend getting Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance and "Forged Alliance Forever".A free community hub for SC: Forged Alliance, it includes "The Vault" from where you can download custom maps and mods (All free). And it is only place for online play. The campaign is really solid and stands on its feet, but the main focus is on multiplayer.There really is no game to compare this to. It is a RTS, it is not a 4X RTS. Yet it's more than a normal RTS. I would call it a quarter of its way to a 4X RTS. The game is really easy to get into, but it's a lot like Starcraft where you need to spend time playing it to get good. On a last note: you play other games to feel like you command an army or a small force. You play this game to feel like you command you command EVERYTHING. Much like the Emperor in 40K. Remember to get Forged Alliance Forever. Also don't get Supreme Commander 2, it sucks Also UEF for the win.

												SupCom is war on a huge scale, a game where powerful death machines are capable of wiping out hundreds of units before they are brought to their knees and maps are measured in tens of kilometres.  Automation and specialised units let you plan outlandish offensives involving multiple coordinated strikes.It's not easy to figure out the economy but if you stick with it I promise you'll love it.  If you can't figure out how to balance your economy or need prettier graphics give SupCom 2 a try.  It loses some of the charm but is a lot easier to learn how to play.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												This is the best. Do not tell me about the others, for this one is the best. In no other game I have seen can you build a sprawling military complex, and then build several military complexes each with specific functions. I have built naval bases, radar stations, listening points, walls, artillary bastions and air bases cloaked from radar. I have sent vast fleets to patrol the oceans, I have made refueling stations where spy planes and bombers alike refuel within sight of a walled complex humming with fifty power generators. I have rolled out tanks and bots in intricate military formations and panned the camera down to see my army rumble over hills, kicking up dirt and barging through forests. I have launched nukes and razed my enemies with gunships the size of mountains.What I have NOT done is endure a measly RTS where you and your opponent start at opposite ends of a tiny map, build one land factory, one mine and two guard towers, and race to get the super unit. Forged Alliance doesn't do that. Forged Alliance treats you like a general, not a MOBA player.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												This game is the standalone expansion of the original supreme commander. nevertheless it plays the same, and we wouldn't have it any other way. In supreme commander you don't just fight a battle, you create an entire war zone. Supreme commander focuses on ALL aspects of war; naval, air, land, radar, transports, defense turrets, resource production and managment, adaptation, vetranacity, nukes, nuke submarines (ftw), even shields and anti nukes not to mention the experimental units (extreme game changers). This game takes strategy to a whole new level with different factions and different units. The game itself wven gives you a menu to mod it, and the mods for this game are outstanding. But this is definatley a game for more experienced players, for those who are new or just getting into these games i would suggest supreme commander 2. the second game is...simpler...its known as a shadow of its former self but the gameplay is easier to understand and control but all the while ruining the game with the experimental factories.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Supreme Commander Forged Alliance or SupCom Fa (My rough view of such game):The game that justifies "Supremacy","Command" and "Epic Proportions". Despite being a stand alone expansion perhaps projects itself of being the best game of the series through prevailing through the years of its active release while in a way it shares positive similarities with SupCom 1 and SupCom 2 (less). It presents a redefined approach through its differences.The game displays a literally huge project of future technology battling it out within these factions that players can choose. Each with a unique playstyle. All with the same goal of supremacy.SupCom Fa does a superb job at defining the genre of "real time strategy". Having the capabilities of generating large scale battles across complex maps. To the simple yet fluid battles that take into account miniscule details from the player.Most of the time games span from early-mid-late game transisition like all strategy games.There is never an idle state and if that is the case expect the unexpected. From the dreaded nuclear launch, surprise experimentals,innovative strategies or just a total economy stall.Heading into SupCom Fa's later years most people nowadays play on the Forged Alliance forever client(requies copy of game).A cosy community keeping this ancient treasure alive and updated. A testimony of how tenacious SupCom Fa is to its fans and providing the all out RTS experience. A true recommendation for fans of the RTS genre. Be weary of the somewhat steep learning curve and required dedicated time needed to play and maybe having to learn. But that is a worthy price to pay for what great potential can be mined from SupCom Fa.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												This is an absolutely amazing RTS that is an improved standalone version of the original Supreme Commander. This version is by all means better than the original game with new units, a new race/faction, and a new campain. This game is kept alive over almost a decade after it's release with an amazing playerbase and modding community at Forged Alliance Forever (http://faforever.com)It's graphics are amazing for 2006, it doesn't need a great computer to run, it has hundreds and hundreds of mods adding units and maps, it has a great competitive and casual community, and it has the best gameplay mechanics of any RTS I've played.If you have questions to ask me about the game, please do not add me on Steam. Please either ask me at http://ask.fm/VelocityLP or PM me on Reddit. (http://reddit.com/u/Blaze17145)

												I did have a working knowledge from having played the original, but I needed more than just a refresher. Fans of the series are definitely going to get more than they bargained for with this expansion pack.Faster gameplay, bigger maps, more units, and a new race.Forged Alliance does a good job at being exactly what it is – a stand-alone expansion delivering an entirely new faction to the world of Supreme Commander, a decent single-player campaign playable from any of three human perspectives, and new experimental units for each faction, including four brand-new experimentals for the new faction.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												over 4k hours outside of steam. Best rts ever, i can't like any other rts because simply to put it, they are not as large scale. You can send an army to a enemy base or send over a colossus sized tank, spider, spinning saucer, and more to completly crush the enemy. every second is super important. When your commander sets down for example, and if you don't focus on building an army and sending it before you can be hit, your score on the top right of your screen will show you are lower than most others. The game is just. beautiful to put it. And there are 4 factions, the aeon, the uef, the cybran, and the seraphim. Each with a unique build design and a unique way to play. Cybran get a experimental spider named Monkeylord which deals 2k damage per second, and the average comm has 12k. The uef for example get a tank called a fatboy. Its a mobile base which has powerful main cannons, which deal 200 damage a shot. Weak anti air, 2 repair pads for air forces, and can build units. Please consider buying this game, check out forged alliance forever and on youtube check out gyle. The community is as activeas can be since this game origionally came out in 2007. There are also huge mods avalible to download from moddb and such to add even more, but be careful please. Every mod you activate in the lobby, builds up ram. The program can only hold 2 gigs and with certain programs can use about 2.3gigs of ram. (Large Adress Aware for me) but please keep this game going.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												(This review is mostly for Supreme Commander as a whole, not only the FA expansion)One of my absolute favourites in the RTS genre, this game creates the sense of an actual war with its immense scale and (for its time) very good visuals (still looks pretty good). 4 nations, countless units divided into tiers, a fairly standard for the genre resource collection, and a fresh element (intel gathering) ensures a game with nigh limitless options for strategies, especially on the bigger maps (the largest ones are 80x80km in size, that can give you a rough idea just how big this game is). The expansion (Forged Alliance) brings in even more units, rebalances for existing ones and some new effects as well as a brand new faction (the Seraphim) that make it well worth the price, not to speak of the fact it's a standalone so you can play it without the original SupCom. The game also has mod support, and there are a few really good ones that were made since the game was released (some are still being updated).Simply put, a must-have for any RTS fan, few games will be able to bring you a similarly amazing experience such as this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												As someone who has played 100+ hrs on disc, after I picked it up in 2007, this game is totally worth it. Forged Alliance I never bothered with- but now that I've started it it seems to just add a new campaign and 20 or so units.PROS- An AI that actually (OMG) focuses on economies and defenses!- So many units, C&C can eat its hat(s)- Great modding community- Hours and hours of play vs Normal AI (C&C Hardcore is easier than them)- racked up about 9 hrs in one single game.- MASSIVE maps. Let's just say a massive artillery piece can't get half of one.- ACTIVE physics. Fire that nuke at the wrong time? Air force is gettin' halved, baby.- BIIGGGGGG economy requirements. You can't plop a Tiberium refinery and be done. You need to fight to secure Mass from enemies, and you need a ♥♥♥♥ ton of Energy.- AIs send lots of scouts at you, and engineers to remote locales to secure Mass- even sending bomber squadrons on sorties into your territory to take out a Mass collecter, then sending an engineer to rebuild it in their nameCONS- AIs focus on air.. But that may have something to do with me building lots and lots of gunships.- AI defenses too good- you'll need several hundred units to break through- AIs build massive armies... and then don't do a damn thing with them- SO MUCH MASS REQUIREMENT. I have over 15 T3s, and it doesn't make enough to build troops and a single building at once.- Interface sucks compared to original SupCom.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												AHH!!!!!! BEST GAME EVER!!!! Full of explosion (Micheal Bay), excitment, strategy and teamwork. You got 4Fractions. Got the UEF, Cybran Aeon, and Serephim. Each fraction specialize in different areas. If its ground, navel or air. Thats your job to find out what each does. This is my top most FAVOURITE game!! I recommand this game 1000%!! Land:You got you T1 units. Light tanks, light artillery, anti air and scout. Basic units with light armour light damge. Good units to harras someone with in the early game;)You then have your T2 units. Meduim tanks/Walkers, missle launchers, shields and stealth troops. Great Units to over take a bunch of T1 and destroy base.You got you T3 Units. Heavy tanks, mortor units and some ant air as well. Amzing troops for taking out just about anything. Even experimentals:0You then got you experimentals. Got you Monkey Lord which is in the second picture, your Fat Boy which is also in the second picture in the back and much more ranging to air and artillery. Some dangerous and far range and some at close range. Dont want to get near these guy.Air:You got your T1 units. Interceptors, bombers, light gunships, scouts and transports. Great units to take control of the sky, for the beggining of course.Got your T2 units. Gunships, fighter/bomber, suicides and transports. Great units to deny any ground attack coming your way.You have your T3 units. Heavy gunships, Heavy bombers that are super deadly, and your fighter. Greaet troops to secure your air control and MURDER and enemy base.Then you got your Experimentals. Deadly from the sky but has weak armour. One run from the Serephim bomber and your a goner. Got your saucers and your heavy, HEAVY gunship.Navel:You got your T1 Units. Frigates, Submarines, and anti air. Great units to take conrtol of the water and Tech up.You got Your T2. Got your Destroyers, Cruisers and submarines. Great units to bombared the land from the water at a great distance. Use these units to support you ground and navelYou have your deadly T3 units. Battleships, cruisers and submarines with NUKES!!!!!!!!Then got experimentals. got your omega submarine too your floating fortress!!And of course you got your engineers. Structures:Over 50 structures!!!! 50!!! Got you energy, mass, air and ground defences, artilerry, wall sections, troperdo defence, radar, land/air/navel factory and so much more. Even experimental structures. Resources: Now this is all cool but you cant just build them right away. Whats the fun in that. You got your 2 resources that are the most important thing in the game beside your commander. Let me repeat that, you got your 2 resources that are the most important thing in the game beside your commander!! You have your mass and energy. More you got, the faster you can build and tech up for better troops and structures. If you are low, might want to fix that because your enemy will take advantage of that.Commander: Most important thing in the game. Your commander(Which is you) dies, its game over. Commander has several upgrades. Each fraction has different upgrades on there Com. Gun upgrade, Tech upgrade to stealth. Much that you wil have to find out for your self.Well I think Iv'e said WAY too much already. Got carried away by how AMAZING this game is. Now it might say only 23 hours but Iv'e played over 500+ hours on my other account!! Also including all the hours I have played in FAF (Forged Alliance Forever). Come check out the website and download it. Thousands of people playing right now!! This is by far my most favourite game!! Join us!! Cmon. I know you want too:)111/10

Posted: January 22, 2014
												First, my Vanilla Supcom Review:One of my favourite RTS's by  one of my favourite people, enough said.Not really: Supreme Commander is to this day an RTS whose scale rivals even upcoming projects such as the MMORTS Novus Aeterno. It doesn't get much more full scale than this. Each player commanding a thousand units is a common occurrence, as is an entire map scarred by artillery and nuclear bombs. Destructive environments, submersible tank-factories, beautiful graphics even for 6 years old, and a very solid if simple campaign make this game one of the best possible $15 buys in the RTS world at this time, please do yourself the favour of getting it.And now, Forged Alliance:Forged Alliance truly expands the Supreme Commander experience if the word was ever properly defined. Bringing new units, maps, a fresh new campaign and that campaign centering around a completely new playable race, Forged Alliance is also one of the best possible buys of the genre, particularly the gold edition with both games, for a very reasonable $20.Oh yea, and not only are there some awesome modders still very much active, but at the time of this review, the multiplayer servers are still on. Not sure about you guys, but that's a deal maker/breaker for me.

Posted: December 19, 2011
												A good and complex RTS title. If you like epic battles and science fiction than this is probably the game for you. The campaign is nice though nothing exceptional (and if you want to play it I suggest starting with "Supreme Commander" instead of this stand-alone expansion) but the game truly shines in Skirmish & Multiplayer.Maps range from about 20x20km to about 80x80km while units meassure between 10 and 100+ meters in size and ranges vary froma couple hundred meters to several kilimeters.Every battle feels epic, realistically scaled and just great! (Though the ressource management might need some time to get used to - but once you are it's great as well!)

Posted: March 13, 2014
												As the saying goes, "Don't judge a book by it's cover." Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is exactly that way. Although it doesn't have many pictures or even a video to introduce itself, it's a fantastic game that adds the extra nation of the Seraphim into the playable category. As one of it's popular tags suggests, this game is very underrated and is a suprisingly fun game. It ranges from the ground, to the sea, and to the air all the while containing massive mechanical deathbots capable of mass destruction and many a big boom. Forged Alliance also comes with a vast number of mods which can add a lot to the gameplay and are a great way to spice up the game a bit if your starting to get tired of it. Ultimately, I highly recommend this game and strongly encourage you to make the purchase.

Posted: May 14, 2014
												This game is about explosions. This is evident because the default gameplay victory condition involves AT LEAST one explosion. WHen you start a match, your main unit spawns, the armoured comand unit (ACU). The goal of the game is to destroy all enemy ACUs. did i mention that when you kill an ACU it causes a nuclear explosion? You start by constructing a base, building resources extractors, power genrators, and factories. out of these factories come engineers and machines that are supposed to make other machines explode. There are several tiers of units. Tier one are rather small grunt type units, tanks and small mechs. tier two the tanks planes and ships get bigger, with bigger weaponry. you unlock thigns like tactical missel launchers and artilery pieces. Tier three is where all the badass units are. There are 4 factions in this game UEF, think of America on super space robot steroids, The Illuminate, a relligious group that's semi fanatical led by a princess. The badass cyborgs lef by a ginius who is somwhere around 900 years old. and then thier are the Seraphim, which are basiclly alien ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s out to comit nearly galactic genocide. There is also a tier four so to speak, its called the "experimentals". Exprimental units highlight what this game is about: Big ♥♥♥♥ing robots with big ♥♥♥♥ing cannons. And Lasers, did i mention the lasers. you know what? ive talked to much

Posted: January 4, 2015
												This is an excellent RTS especially considering its age. The factions are well balanced, game modes varied, and means of winning diverse.  Further, the tech tree is not to hard to learn while mastery of hte game takes longer (as it should). If you like RTS games which require building an economy and commanding an army, Supremem Commander: Forged Alliance is for you.

Posted: December 19, 2015
												It's not often a spiritual sequel lives up to the glory of it's predecessor - Supreme Commander (And this expansion, Forged Alliance), is one of those rare gems.With it's roots in the masterpiece that was Total Annihilation, Supreme Commander keeps that incredible feel of a glorious RTS with four well-balanced factions, unique units, each with their own checks and balances found among the other factions, mod compatibility, stunning graphics, intuitive but rewarding tech trees, and... The list just goes on. When you fight in Supreme Commander, anything can happen. You've begun your siege against the enemy and have an array of missile units; but wait, the enemy has tactical missile defenses, rendering your forces useless! Luckily for you, your chosen battlefield was just in range of your navy, who begin pummeling the shore with their artillery... Until their airborne torpedo bombers are on your radar... Did you bring AA cruisers? Or do you have your own air force in waiting?This is RTS at it's finest. As one who sunk countless hours into Total Annihilation as a child (and as an adult), this is one game that lives up to the greatness of it's origins, and is an absolute steal at $14.99. Give this one a try, you won't regret it.And if you're into older games, want to try the predecessor to SupCom, with a soundtrack epicly composed by Jeremy Soule (you may know him from Skyrim, Dungeon Siege, or Guild Wars 2 to name a few), check out Total Annihilation.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Fantastic kind of old school strategy game.  Like its daddy total annihilation this is great fun to play.  Lots of valid strategies, plenty of units and buildings to fiddle with.  A decent selection of maps.  You can zoom in and micro control your units, or zoom right out and send them around as dots on the map for bigger battles.  Simple economy setup metal/energy.  Its a pretty simple game at heart but with enough complexity that you'll keep coming back and back back.  Please ignore my time in game, I only added it to steam recently but have played it for many many years from my original disk copy!  Can be bought for a bargain today and I would say its aged very gracefully.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												WOW this game is good lets review it (story) now i cant say to much about the story because ive been playing online and skirmish but i will try my best its about the 3 factions UEF cybran and aeon (this is there old name) there is also a new faction that i cant remember the name of but its the enemy faction of the game anyway the other factions team up to stop them. thats all i can really say about the story as i havnt played much of it.(skirmish)this mode is great fun you set up a match options mods whatever and then you start an all out war with nukes tanks and jets all fighting it out you controle all of these units make them and destroy them the online mode is similer but with humans instead of computers.(mods) unlike the sequel of the game mods are actually supported with a full mod menu with start of mods that you can choose from.(cons)there isnt many however there are a few such as if you dont pick fast on your gameplay options the game is realy slow which may make the game boring to casual players aswell as this sometimes the AI is very overwhelming sometimes even on easy mode i sometimes struggled to win especially for casual players.(overall)this game is honestly better than SC2 however i feel like casual players wont enjoy the game and should stick to SC2 but this game is a masterpeice and i think hardcore RTS fans should pick it up.

												One of the grandest, large scale RTS games i've played. This game deserves every award it gets. Hundreds of units, massive titans, mein gott its so grand! Gigantic battles, death everyhwere, bullets flying and lasers alight; ah, its a true beauty to any warlord to watch. My only real problem with this title is that it is pretty mentally taxing; due to its unqiue building system instead of buying, your resources become drastically more important, my economy tanks fairly frerquently and I crash and burn. I list this as a bad, but this is great for the more masochistic or strategically minded people. People still play online, and the game features skirmish options aganist AI. Overall, I highly recommend to anyone who has the slightest interest in RTS games.

Posted: November 7, 2014
												This is the king of RTS games, and my all time favorite game. You don't play it for the campaign. You play it for AI skirmishes and Multiplayer online matches. Now, you may ask, "What makes this game so special?". Well, the answer is CREATIVITY. I have never encountered a more creative real time strategy game. Ever. Period. After playing this, all other RTS's feel... weak, small, and insignificant. Why have 10 soldiers when you can have 100? Why have a handful of planes when you can build a monstrous flying Sui-saucer with a SPACE LASER BEAM. Why engage in a frontal assault when you can cripple their building economy, or send in stealth units behind their lines to eliminate defenses (This actually happened to me, someone built stealth field generators right on the opposite side of my island, and constructed a whole production facility.)? This game does not encourage blind rushes, or impulse purchasing. Every move needs to be calculated, every defense needs to be perfect, ever strategy needs a backup plan. There are three rules for playing this game- 1. Eliminate the Enemy (obviously). 2. Be intelligent with your decisions. 3. BE CREATIVE. That is what separates this game from the rest, it gives you the tools to be creative! Why spam units when you can construct another base all the way across the map, place your commander there, and wait until the enemy assaults your old base, and when they arrive, you swoop into their main base with planes, transports, and nukes, and annihilate the whole thing! The ability this game gives you, the ability to surprise your opponents, is so satisfying, so perfect, that every time one of my half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥nutcase ideas works, I do a fistpump and spin around in my office chair. If you like to be creative, then this game gets a check on your list. If you like massive scale, another check. If you like robots, lasers, tanks, planes, nukes, artillery, satellites, mobile fortresses, and Flying saucers that would make the aliens from Independence day jealous, then this game is for you.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												Probably one of the greatest strategy games of all time, the creators of Total Annihilation bring us Supreme Commander. The appeal of an RTS lies in unique strategies that always have an advantage and a disadvantage. Knowing what you opponent is doing is half of the battle. The other half is actually trying to carry out your strategy effectively. There are 4 races you can choose from, each with their own units, Aeon, UEF, Cybran and Seraphim. They all have their own strength and weaknesses but ultimately its your own actions that determine the outcome of any game. The only downside, is to play multiplayer effectively, you need the 3rd party client FAF (forged alliance forever) which is hosted externally. There are extra mods and missions which is great. There is a ranking system to play serious games as well. I would definitely recommend this to people who want a challenging RTS

Posted: February 21, 2016
												Supreme Commander: FA  Where does one begin?Born as a spiritual successor to Chris Taylor's revolutionary RTS Total Annihilation, Supreme Commander builds on TA's original formula and simply makes everything better.  Tech levels where weaponry gets more powerful, and expensive.  Land, Air, and Naval units to attack your enemies from all sides.  Being able to que up units and have them set to go to points and attack, patrol, or be air-lifted to places on the map, this game simply does it all for an RTS.  Gorgeous graphics, awesome effects, and a great sound score round it out.  If you are a fan of the RTS genre, this is simply a MUST HAVE/PLAY!The only flaw I can find with the game is that once you have four players with around ~750 units each, the game has to slow down to continue to keep things smooth.  I would love to see something where it could be optimized to be able to take advantage of today's powerful multi-core processors to be able to allow thousands of units to multiple players and render them smoothly in real time.  9.999/10

												WOW this game is good lets review it (story) now i cant say to much about the story because ive been playing online and skirmish but i will try my best its about the 3 factions UEF cybran and aeon (this is there old name) there is also a new faction that i cant remember the name of but its the enemy faction of the game anyway the other factions team up to stop them. thats all i can really say about the story as i havnt played much of it.(skirmish)this mode is great fun you set up a match options mods whatever and then you start an all out war with nukes tanks and jets all fighting it out you controle all of these units make them and destroy them the online mode is similer but with humans instead of computers.(mods) unlike the sequel of the game mods are actually supported with a full mod menu with start of mods that you can choose from.(cons)there isnt many however there are a few such as if you dont pick fast on your gameplay options the game is realy slow which may make the game boring to casual players aswell as this sometimes the AI is very overwhelming sometimes even on easy mode i sometimes struggled to win especially for casual players.(overall)this game is honestly better than SC2 however i feel like casual players wont enjoy the game and should stick to SC2 but this game is a masterpeice and i think hardcore RTS fans should pick it up.

Posted: February 7
												With all the crap RTS's that have come down the pipeline in the recent years, I almost always end up coming back to this game. Don't let the hours on recorded fool you, I've play well over 1000 hours off steam. This game is everything that an RTS needs. It's got distinct factions, is well balance, plenty of units, the feel of real progression, viable units at all tiers of tech, and there is plenty of lore behind it. Do yourself a favor and if you are thinking about buying this game, just do it. You won't regret it. Fair warnign though  there is a bit of a steep learning curve. Just youtube a couple of matches and you'll get the jist. I love this game, and until Chris Taylor tops this, I'll be playing for years to come. (Also, if you want multiplayer, get Forged Alliance Forever)10/10 still the best RTS on the market at the moment.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												This game was released in November 2007 and now, nine years later, is still the most multilayered and yet refined RTS I know of. There are land warfare, air warfare, naval warfare, intelligence warfare, missile warfare and everything inbetween. There are so many options to turn around the tide of battle that you never know when the next surprise is awaiting. The game still looks great, sounds great and feels great to play. There is no itch of gigantomania that this game can not satisfy (if your computer can run it, that is).Granted, there are a few annoying issues (e.g. you can't save mutliplayer saves and performance does drop significantly in apocalyptic end battles that involve thousands of units because barely any game uses multicore capabilities and neither does this one), but that doesn't change that this game is AWESOME. If you have any interest for the RTS genre at all, you need to have played this game. I don't think you'll regret it ;-)

Posted: March 13, 2014
												As the saying goes, "Don't judge a book by it's cover." Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is exactly that way. Although it doesn't have many pictures or even a video to introduce itself, it's a fantastic game that adds the extra nation of the Seraphim into the playable category. As one of it's popular tags suggests, this game is very underrated and is a suprisingly fun game. It ranges from the ground, to the sea, and to the air all the while containing massive mechanical deathbots capable of mass destruction and many a big boom. Forged Alliance also comes with a vast number of mods which can add a lot to the gameplay and are a great way to spice up the game a bit if your starting to get tired of it. Ultimately, I highly recommend this game and strongly encourage you to make the purchase.

Posted: May 19, 2013
												An outstanding RTS that every strategist should buy. A soul succesor to Total Annahilation fans should recongnize the single Commander unit that constructs and attacks.Graphics & Sound:   The game is great on the eyes although this game was released in 2007 the graphics have aged phenomenally. You will need a beefy rig to run it on the highest setting and even at the lowest settings it still looks great. There are some issues with the engineers (construction units) getting lost between buildings.   The game's sound is pretty good but not the greatest. Miniguns sound like sharp and crisp, artillery have an umph to them, and blasters have a laser feel to them. Some sound effects go on loop or are just lounder than other ones around it. One big gripe is that you will not know where something is being attacked when it is off screen you will only hear explosions and projectiles; no marker showing where. The music on the other hand is pretty good music. It amps up when your are battling or under attack and then goes peaceful when it is calm.Gameplay:   Now to the nitty gritty of the game, the gameplay. Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is your typical RTS. The 4 factions (UEF, Cybran, Aeon, and the new Seraphim) feel uniquely different but still fall back on the basics of base building. You start with you commander known as an Armored Command Unit (ACU) that can create a base within minutes. There are to harvestable resources in the game, energy and mass. Energy is collected by building generators; while mass is only collected on limited mass points on the maps. Maps come in different sizes and climates. They range from 5km x 5km jungles to 81km x 81km tundras. The smallest maps are great for rush and harrassment tactics. On the flip side the larger maps are focused on artillery and other later game weapons. Speaking of weapons there are tons defense and offense tactics; from point defense to tactical missles to artillery and to the biggest and most expensive the Nuke. Each factions has 3 Tech levels that are upgraded through factories and your ACU. Each tech brings new units and new buildings that pack a bigger punch than the last. In addition to the 3 different tech levels each factions gain a hand full of experimental units that take a lot of resources to build but reck havoc on enemy units once they are completed.Verdict:   An amazing RTS that deserves more love than it has. I recommend picking it up with a couple of friends. There are endless possibilities that you can play each game and with actually people can be very challenging.8/10

Although most people mod it using the Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) modset.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance  is a more than decent RTS game. and while I still like Supreme Commander 2 better. There is something to say when someone asks you how good Forged Alliance is. The base multiplayer seems to no longer work properly, but coupled with the Forged Alliance Forever mod, you will find that there are still many people playing.  Thus  most of your time will probably be spent in the non Steam multiplayer.Forged Alliance is   a lot "harder" than Supreme Commander 2, and it takes a lot more to learn how to play Forged Alliance well than it does in Supcom 2.  There is a much larger focus on upgrades and micromanagement in Forged Alliance than there is in Supreme Commander 2. This leads to there being much slower longer lasting games than in Supreme Commander 2, where games feel very speedy in comparison. Over all I would definitely reccomend Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance to the more hard core RTS fans, because it is a pretty good RTS. However its age shows in many places and it does require a third party lobby to get any real enjoyment out of your multiplayer experience.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Honestly, if your going to get Supreme Commander, this should be at the top of your priority list. This adds another faction as well as tweaks in the gameplay and mechanics that allow for more play time and more interesting strategy styles. The game itself may seem standard for RTS games but that is more a strength than a weakness. Some more modern RTS games (talking to you Supreme Commander 2) can create a more simplified experience and cause the game to easily become stale and dull, whereas this game follows in line with classics like Age of Empires and even Command and Conquer with a larger unit management and a fun/ever changing atmosphere sure to entertain any RTS fans.If your looking for online play, this game has lost a large fraction in its community in the years and it may prove difficult to find other players online. There is a community online called Supreme Commander Forged Alliance Forever where people looking to play online and continue the life blood of the game gather, so check them out for the best way to find other players online.All in all, this game is fun and fresh for new-time players, and entertaining at least to veterans. Hope you enjoy it as much as I do!See ya, planetside!

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on March 3, 2007 I played the beta for SupCom, so I have to admit, I knew what i was buying. This game is ambitious, and sets out to accomplish alot. The only thing really holding this game back from greatness is the blandness in play style of the races. I will explainGraphically, this game is very appealing, because of its size, scope, and style. It feels like real war, visually, and the mapping possibilities are endless. The maps are a little nondescript sometimes, and the models aren't exactly high poly, but the trade off for size of the battlefield is well worth it.The Orchestral themes are nice, but a little short. It feels like they have about 5 tracks of music for the whole game. The sound effects are just right, but nothing specialGameplay is what really makes this game a winner. The size, scale, variety of tactics and unit types make this game amazing to play, you just have to experience it for yourself, it's awesome.However, barring aesthetic differences, the races play almost identically. I think more could have been done to make their play styles distinctive. That is really this games one failing. It is still very much worth an RTS fans money.  UPDATE: The forged alliance expansion adds a fourth faction: aliens. It's pretty much awesome.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Supreme Commander is a realtime strategy game featuring gameplay similar to Total Annihilation and Planetary Annihilation. Forged Alliance is the standalone "expansion" to the original Supreme Commander, where all the factions are featured including Seraphim which apparently is the alien race that Aeon got it's technology from.Supreme Commander is a game about macro-strategy and production above micro-strategy. There are no "unit abilities" in the same vein as in games such as Starcraft II. The game features a "Streaming Economy", where you can build anything regardless if you have the resource stored or not, but the building speed is dictated by how much resource you can stream into said building. So if you only have 5 metal to stream into a building but the building speed maximum would require 10 - you would theoretically only build at 50% speed. You can store more resources through building storage buildings, which acts as a resource buffer for you, but storage of resources are not infinite - the production that exceeds demands is simply lost.The game features a lot of UI improvements like being able to set up ferry lines and limited automation, repitition and the like. It lacks a few of the improvements from Planetary annihilation but so does planetary lack from improvements from this title.In the end it's just a great game overall, while it doesn't have the best of themes like the drama involved in even regular games of Company of Heroes - it's still a great game in its own right. It is deeply underappreciated game and one of my absolute favorite games of all time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Total Annihilation grew up, moved out of its parent's house, and then melted the entire planet's face.Seriously, everything I liked about TA is in SupCom in some fashion, but better. SC added features that (at the time) no other RTS had, like the megamap. Now, if your game doesn't have a megamap, don't bother to come to school - the other kids will just laugh and push your face into the dirt. Looking at you, Ashes.Shields are also a favorite of mine. In TA and other RTSes, when your defenses repel the infidels, they take damage that must be repaired. With shields, as long as the bubble stays up, the shield will regenerate over a relatively short period, and the defenses will keep on keepin' on. There are mods that add super bubbles (shields) that can stop practically anything, which leads to some "battle of Hoth" instances where ground forces must be sent in to take out the shield generator (if you sprint units inside the shield, they can attack things within) before the long-range bombardment destroys everything else. It is super fun.The game isn't perfect, though. The one overriding issue, apart from the developer being dead and no official multiplayer list servers, is performance. The game was developed in a time where dual-core PCs were a new thing, and was quite revolutionary in its multithreaded design. The simulation and the rendering pipeline are broken out to two threads, and this helps the game run fast on multicore systems. Unfortunately, the sim thread could really use being broken down into multiple threads itself. Mid to late game, even though the FPS will still be 100+, units will act slow. They move slow, react slow, missles and cannon shots will move slower. This is the sim thread being overwhelmed by the 2000+ units running about. Since the dev is gone, this will never be fixed, and that's a damn shame since the game is practically the perfect RTS otherwise.Regardless, buy this and enjoy! Actually runs really well on my I7-4770k throughout a match and is as much fun now as then!

												Although this game is old, i will show the pros and cons (pros won) of this game compared to Supreme Commander 2-Pros-A new ACU into the game.-Tech only comes from upgraded factories/ACU's/and engi's.-Can Build Multi ACU's for picking up or guarding the frontlines.-Upgradeable buildings are very useful instead of just reclaiming them for a better one.-AI adds more chalange than the AI in SC2-Experementels Look really cool and Pack alot of damage-Transportation Airships Have animation when picking up land units-The Logs and animation to the people talking in the campain are outstanding and is affected on what ACU type you choose-Upgradeable ACU's on the diffrent parts of the ACU, Example: right hand: Tech 3 buildable buildings.-Some Land Units (includeing the ACU) can walk in the water saveing a bunch of time instead of haveing to go around the water-WALLS, LOTS OF THEM! USE TO DESTROY EXPEREMENTALS, WALLS OP!!!!!!!!!!-When Destroying Main ACU, The explosion leaveing in the remains are really good includeing the strategeic missle launcher that has the same explosive effects.-One of the top ten RTS Games in Rock Paper Shotgun.-Cons-The graphics are lesser than SC2-More or less experementals-animation on ACU's are somewhat to little impress me-Less levels for campain-Building a Tech 3 unit takes more than half the time it takes for SC2 Nukes to set up, every 2 Tech 3 units is one nuke ready to launch.9/10 I think you should all go buy it rather than SC2 and make sure you BUILD WALLS 4 OPNESS!!!!!

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is the expansion that brings the Supreme Commander community to life. There is one new campaign that can be played through three times, once for each faction, with some differences in dialogue and secondary objectives between factions. New units add to mid- and late-game strategy, and the new faction gives greater variety in multiplayer games.What sets Supreme Commander apart from other RTS games is a combination of in-game cinematic graphics and the tactical nature of viewing the field. A player can rotate the map in almost any direction and at any angle to see units firing on each other. This is the first RTS game I've played that uses zooming for navigating the field as an alternative to a minimap. If you zoom out far enough, units show up as icons that immediately tell the player what role each unit plays. This unique "tactical view" also has a dual-screen mode, which allows the player to monitor and act on two places on the battlefield at once.The community of Forged Alliance players is still alive and well, with thousands of active players on a community-driven lobby (Forged Alliance Forever, FAF) that also keeps the game up-to-date.If you plan to get Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, get it together with the original Supreme Commander. The two games are like computer desk and chair; they each function fine on their own, but put them together and you get a whole different experience.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												Probably the best RTS out there. You'll want to pick up the expansion, Forged Alliance, as well. Units conduct base building. I always liked that about a RTS. Huge scale battles, large tech tree (4 levels), 2 resource economy, 3 factions (4 on FA), good campaign and decent modding community. Naval units, air and ground forces plus point defenses, long range artillery, strategic weapons, shields, you name it, this game has it all. Easy to use but complex interface. Nothing quite like bombarding an enemy's base with heavy artillery and experimental units. The spiritual successor to Total Annihilation. Highly recommend to any RTS fan out there.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Dots fighting simulator 2011.RTS Gameplay : Solid, Extremely fun, Well done.Visual Arts : Lacking, To say the least, No personality in here, Can not tell the difference between one unit to another, Beside their size change that is noticable and experimental units that actually do look different from each other.Map terrain looks extremely generic, Nothing really stands out there.Voice Acting : Bad, You are better with subtitles only.SoundFX : Bad, The amount of bass there is for almost every sound is huge, And it's mostly just generic explosion sounds.Music : Unnoticeable.Multiplayer: The community seems to be trying to survive , with FAF lobby mode included.Storyline : Ok so you have dots on one side of the map, And dots on the other side.The dots on one side want to destroy the dots on the other side for having different color.They do it by drawing lines.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												I would recommend this game to anyone that is a fan of Massive scale RTS games.Pros.Massive scale, Land, Air and Sea!Good diversity in the factions, each one has they're strengths and weaknesses.Experimental units that can help break turtle defenses.Artillery structures and units that can truly be called artillery (long ranged not just longer then a standard unit)Resource management that makes you think, other wise you won't have much resources.Shields, layered shields that can help absorb damage.Tiered progression, You have tier 1-3 units and structures that in turn might be less effective against higher tiers but still have a use.Great graphics.Can't just spam units to win.Cons.Some what un-optimized, can be taxing on computers.Air Units can be some what over powered.Campaign was a bit short.Each faction while diverse, was lacking in specializations.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												The number of hours steam shows is a lie, I have probably a few thousand hours into playing.  This is one of my favorite games.  I am currently playing it on my third computer.  It is the spiritual successor of Total Annihilation and very well done.  Well worth the money as it will end up costing you mere pennies per hour.  Like all RTS games you start with a few basic units, usually just your commander.  You then build factories, resource gathering, and military.  You then Explore, expand exploit and exterminate.  In supreme commander you have 4 tiers of units T1 to T3 and then experimental units, which are very expensive and take a long time to build, but are essentially game enders.  Each of the 4 races has its own unique units, strengths and weakenesses.  The experimentals also fill fairly specific roles, making enemy engineer capture a significant boost to your combat power.  It has been out long enough now that the units are all pretty well balanced.  If you are a fan of RTS games, I highly recommend this one.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												I’ve been playing games for years. You know how you drift from one good game to another?  Going from Starcraft, Oblivion, Fallout 3, Skyrim, etc…But every time those games get a little old,  I always go back to this one.  For almost 10 years, this has always had me come back for more competitive fun. Good community, great videos online (Gyle, Brinkof Insanity, etc..).  This is truly one of the best games around, it just wasn’t as popular.  Be warned, it does have a very steep learning curve.  But all other strategy games are shallow compared to the depth of this game.(I also play through a player run organization called FAF {Forged Alliance Forever}.  If you play it go through their much better lobby and ranking system.  It is worth it!)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												10 years later and this is still my favorite strategy game on the market. If you want strategy, this game is the definitive RTS.Many things I like about this game come down to preference, but if you want a strategy game with resource streams (continual and infinite resource collection), this game is the best of the category. There is very little micromanagement that has to be done to produce units, leaving the player to focus entirely on his/her armies. If there is one thing that makes this game shine, it is this lack of serious micromanagement in production and base-building.Supreme Commander is a shining example in the genre of Real Time Strategy.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												This game would have been the wet dream of Churchill, Ceasar Dwight. D. Eisenhower or anyone else who has to command  in times of war. Because you can do EVERYTHING you want in a massive scale. If its transporting hundreds of Bombers/Gunships via a submersible Submarine, start a nuke from another submarine, annihilate your enemy with satellite-mounted-lasers or just bombarding your enemy back into the stone ages by using long-range artillery installations. Altough the game is old, you can still find a lot of guys to play with via Forgeed Alliance Forever, with a very vivid community. Only disadvantage is the high strain on your CPU and for beginners the tough opponents in multiplayer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												The greatest RTS of all time.  Period.Pros:+ Unit chain-pathing from a source building to create patrols.  Good players might not use this as much, but crappy players like me will no doubt LOVE the visual affect of watching the patrols running.+ 3 levels of technology for all units in a logarithmic expense.  I.e. it will take forever to get to the next tech if you try to jump too early, so the time building up creates a layering of the playing field.+ The single-player campaign is nice.  If you are interested in this, get the package that has FA and the orgiinal game to get the whole campaign.+ The campaign is the only place you'll hear voice acting.  All the sounds in a skirmish are just robotic machine noises and they are all nice to listen to.  The play field becomes this noisy droning clattering thing.+ This was the first game to have the feature "zoom in wherever my mouse is pointing".+ Templates are cool!Cons:- The UI seems old(ish) compared to recent games.  So don't make comparisons!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2013
												RTS: Subjective score: 8/10So you think you have the brains for strategy ?Well, this baby is all about strategy (it comes down to tactics as well as it is real time strategy, but if we compare this to - lets say - WC III, then WC III was heavily tactical RTS). In this game, you might send your troops in blind suicide mission to harass the enemy only to get some precious seconds to manage your economy/constructions.A good commander will have to:- Control key strategic points;- Pick the right types of constructs for the right type of the enemy's defenses/incoming attack waves;- Know when to strike & when to dig in and focus on technology;- Manage Land, Air, Naval (+submersible) units;- Utilise Intel (scout, radar, optical vision, radar stealth, even optical stealth);- Utilise strategic weapons such as artillery support for those turtle types.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												This game is amongst the best strategy games that has ever been made. It has tons of content, a good campaign and its easy to learn. There is one single design problem though that puts me off. There are ram limitations in the game engine which means that if you play with 4 ai bots or more your game will slow down to slow motion in late game. This happens because the engine cant use all the memory of your computer.The game is still worth a shot though as it is a unique strategic experience that you wont find in mosto ther strategy games. I personally love it even though it has ram limitations. Good graphics, fantastic gameplay, good unit variation, every faction is different gameplay wise and the music is fine. I rate this game 8/10 but from a neutral perspective I would rate it 6/10 not because the game is bad but because of the ram problems.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												I have not played a ton of RTS games in my gaming life but I have tried a bunch and watched videos about lots more. Forged Alliance is the best. There are SOME balance issues I guess but that can be debated.... like these super mega bad♥♥♥♥♥units called experimentals can just rip though a player's base more often then not. The balance is the massive cost of resources and length of time to produce one.But there are a lot of units. ALl of which can be used in different tactical senarios. For instance, the lowest tired and weakest assult bots can be easily defeated but in a swarm of them air lifted down they can swarm-fire gound and air defenses if done right. Higher tierd units cost more and take longer to produce but 3 tech III bomber jets can do a great deal of crippeling damage if your tactics are sound... moreso then a swarm of gunships.There is a degree of rock-paper-siscors to the RTS element but there are other factors as well. Tactics, player skill and even terrain play bigger roles then this group of units vs that group. You can zoom out to look at a 5km map and see all your units as small icons or zoom down to look at the legs of one of your smaller units. Tilt the camera around to actually SEE the terrain layout. Putting artillary units behind a small hill can protect them from tanks, for example... well, if the tanks don't flank the hill.There's a campaign but its ot that good. Fights and maps are fun but playing solo against AI is more fun to me then solo campaign. I owned this for years before I activated it on my steam account I have maybe 300 hours in it? So this is my go-to game when I wanna create an army or robots to blow up other robots. And there's nukes too.4/5 ...there is a player run client called FAF, or Forged Alliance Forever, that people use to play matches. Some game mod mods are also there as well as a very realistic hand coded AI by fans called Sorian AI. The AI sent me an IM saying "I have a present for you..." once before it launched a nuke at me. I give FAF 5/5 but you need a beefy modern PC to handle it well.

Posted: October 26, 2014
												I'm sure that I WOULD like this game. I'm sure that I WOULD put a lot of time into it.But I can't.I can't because I don't understand it.The tutorial is poor to say the least. It tells you the absolute bare bones of the entire game and then shoves you into the deep end with no knowledge of what to do. I'm going to have to resort to to YouTube and finding out how to do it there which I don't like doing because I don't think you should have to. In the first mission you are given a half destroyed base with no knowledge of whether or not you should repair the base or build a new one. All that I would ask for is a little bit of handholding at the start of the mission to get you going. I'm going to reccomend this game to people who already know what they're doing with this series. If you don't, try it at your own risk.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
Product received for free
												This... This game is from my childhood. it started with my dad buying the game Supreme commander. As a child it was VERY confusing to me. I dont really remember how many missions did i do but boy was i surprised when i came back to this after 4-6 years. (Yes i used the CD key to get SC and SC:FA to steam) When i found out supreme commander had another thing called Forged alliance i wanted to try it so bad, that i literally installed it the second i watched videos on it. Supreme commander is a game where you will literally FORGET about the textures on some places, For example a factory. it looks like its made in 16 bit or more when you look at it VERY closely. but when you dont really care about zooming on it and "checking" for good textures, it really looks like a clean, greatly made factory. Anyways Supreme commander has that kind of "interest" on it from large scale battles to building a base with checkpoints, scout bases, anything you can probably imagine in a RTS game. once i made 4 experimentals and rushed through the battlefield with them, assisted by ground troops and fighters, it struck me. "This game is great!" i said, and continued to nuke the enemy base and♥♥♥♥♥♥them with an army of mine. In short, SC:FA is a game where intelligence, positioning, strategizing, and executing are vital parts that you will understand in this Very greatly made game.Buy it, Commander. and show those darn enemies what a blast you are! now go to the battlefield! MAKE the enemy fear you! kneel upon you! And nuke the-Thats enough writing for me, whew. PS: This game WONT work on windows 10, so stay in windows 7!PPS: This game now has a community driven lobby named FAF = Forged Alliance Forever where you can decimate other players bases in great satisfaction!Peace. (The word thats non-existent in this game)

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												This review covers Supreme Commander and Supreme Commander Forged Alliance. Get both!One of the greatest RTS games of all time.If you like commanding hundreds of sea, air, and land units please read on.Don't let the low hours on Steam trick you. Eight of my friends and I bought this game on CD years ago. We would routinely play 6 to 8 co-op or multiplayer (free for all) games on LAN before the Internet speeds really got fast. I've got at least 1000 hours in this game with all the weekend LAN parties hosted at a bachelor pad.This game ruined my RTS experience by introducing or near perfecting some techniques.1. Virtually unlimited queueing of orders (patrol, move, etcetera). I've never hit a limit. I would reckon that I have had at least 100 orders queued without any issue to tens of different unit groups.2. Large scale battles. Each side can have hundreds of units (we've had 8 sides in one large battle).3. Mouse zoom in/out. I can't explain in words the many ways this feature is plain useful and should be the standard in RTS games. You can zoom into a low level (one unit) and out to see the entire map and units are then represented as particular icons (easily identifiable). You can issue any command or select any unit from low to high level zooms. It's plain awesome.4. True faction faction and unit differences. Big difference between tier 1, 2, 3, and experiental units.5. Interesting upgrade paths for commander with multiple paths (Builder, fighter, stealth, etc).6. Short cut keys to do same thing as mouse.7. Four factions that look, feel, and really behave different.8. True land, sea (above and below), and air units.9. Transports (air or sea) with fantastic transport queueing/ferry options.10. Graphics look great, even for an old game.11. Replayability (different campaigns as different factions, co-op, multiplayer, maps)12. Experimental units.13. Game balance. Almost every unit has a counterpart. Want to nuke people? Want to build anti-nuke system?14. Automation of engineers (patrol duty) to clear battle fields of wrecked metal or terrain and repair stationary units.15. Massive selection of buildings and units16...I'm sure I'm leaving stuff out.I'm trying to convince my wife to let me buy five more copies when on sale for my children. There are a few potty words in the campaign (hell, damn, etc) so I'm not sure if I can yet. I started to play this game again after years of playing other games. This RTS set the standard in so many areas that is effectively made me a critic of other RTS games that could continue the standard and improve it. None have.Note: I am playing with Windows 10 64-bit operating system with Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance executables set to Windows compatibility (Windows XP SP2). If I do not set this, then game crashes between levels. With it set, I haven't crashed yet.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
Product received for free
												This... This game is from my childhood. it started with my dad buying the game Supreme commander. As a child it was VERY confusing to me. I dont really remember how many missions did i do but boy was i surprised when i came back to this after 4-6 years. (Yes i used the CD key to get SC and SC:FA to steam) When i found out supreme commander had another thing called Forged alliance i wanted to try it so bad, that i literally installed it the second i watched videos on it. Supreme commander is a game where you will literally FORGET about the textures on some places, For example a factory. it looks like its made in 16 bit or more when you look at it VERY closely. but when you dont really care about zooming on it and "checking" for good textures, it really looks like a clean, greatly made factory. Anyways Supreme commander has that kind of "interest" on it from large scale battles to building a base with checkpoints, scout bases, anything you can probably imagine in a RTS game. once i made 4 experimentals and rushed through the battlefield with them, assisted by ground troops and fighters, it struck me. "This game is great!" i said, and continued to nuke the enemy base and♥♥♥♥♥♥them with an army of mine. In short, SC:FA is a game where intelligence, positioning, strategizing, and executing are vital parts that you will understand in this Very greatly made game.Buy it, Commander. and show those darn enemies what a blast you are! now go to the battlefield! MAKE the enemy fear you! kneel upon you! And nuke the-Thats enough writing for me, whew. PS: This game WONT work on windows 10, so stay in windows 7!PPS: This game now has a community driven lobby named FAF = Forged Alliance Forever where you can decimate other players bases in great satisfaction!Peace. (The word thats non-existent in this game)

content:
Posted: February 6
												Forged Alliance improves upon Supreme Commander in every aspect. The only issue I really have with it, is that it's a standalone game and that they did not include these improvements in the base game, which could REALLY benefit from that.Some examples:- Better and smaller UI. Everything takes less clicks, is easier to find and takes up less space, giving you more space for glorious battles- Graphics seem to have been improved a bit as well- Land units now actually march in sensible formations from what I can tell. Previously the formation was torn apart when units were moving. This is better now.- Units in general respond better and faster to commands. Terrain navigation is much smoother.- Naval units no longer ignore commands are get stuck on terrain as far as I can tell. Previously naval units adopted ridiculously large formations and parts of your naval force would simply not move to a location if it thought there wasn't enough space. This might have possibly been, because naval units also had a tendency to get stuck on one another...- Air units are easier to handle and operate more efficiently it seems. They also now finally use landing pads the way they were designed to be used: USE ALL OF THEM, not just one when issueing the refuel order. It was pathetic to see 50 air units circle 1 landing pad when 10 were available. Now they use everything as it should be.The campaign spans another 6 missions which you can play as any of the 3 core factions with new units for each. However, you can't simply switch factions in the campaign and the missions do not change based on what faction you're playing. Just some dialogue and vaguely different units (since all 3 factions have at least mostly units that fulfill similar roles, just with different stats and armaments). Speaking of stats: The game has been completely rebalanced it seems. Also, there is a new faction you fight against in the campaign, which you can also play as in Multiplayer. Great "addon".

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Originally bought it at release from gpg, I watched as gpg maintained it with decent attentionand effectiveness for a few years after release as I lost interest.GPG did a fairly good job maintaining the game, I look forward to the future work of thedevelopers, wherever the talent ends up. The company failed, but the game succeeded.The engine is solid, the graphical effects are reasonably solid in terms of being efficient,you can customize the graphic quality extensivly... allowing the game to work on a weaksystem... maybe an old laptop! (use a mouse)You should buy this game if you are a fan of rts. It may not be your favorite rts but ittakes some extremely unique advances from its peers, indeed it is fundementally not likeothers in the genre.  Its not anything like starcraft 2, and is not in competition with it,one cant reasonably argue which is the better rts... they are not similar enough to compare.this is an engrossing strategy game, the campaign is mediocre but the replay value of the gameis very high due to the extreme variability of the economic and military considerations based onmap position, distance from enemy... geography is a huge factor. Satisfaction from carnageis pretty high :D carnage lovers rejoice... there can be so much wreckage on a battlefield thatyour army cant even cross the god damned thing... I have dropped nukes on battlefields just to obliterate wreckage and pass trough.THAT is carnage!buy this game on sale. It is not the best thing ever but it is unique and stands alone in its field.the control and the scale are not repeated elsewhere.(the crews responsible for cavedog, TA, and  planetary anihilation have been made up of manyof the same people .)
