content:
Posted: January 7
												The reason for my low hours is due to me having a retail copy before this. This version was DRM free as far as I can remember.But why I dislike this game.You spend far too much time zoomed out and it honestly ruins the game. But because of how the game was made you can't really avoid this feature.All units are just unoriginal. The only unique stuff goes too the T4 units.The AI in SupCom have issues. For one it sends a long conga line of units that will barely be a threat. It keeps building T1 units when I have T2 and T3 Defense put up or have large T4 units strolling around.Late game are ended in some ways.Large amount of T4 units.Even Larger amount of ground T3 units.Mass amount of T3 Gunships.If you can mass produce a higher tier there is really no choice to go back. A T1 stand little chance against T2 and even less to T3.The game will still start to lag a bit when massive stuff are going on so I'm just gonna blame the engine for that. This is with just 1 AI and 2 human players.I've gotten Total Annihilation to work on Windows 10 and for me that is more enjoyable and a better game. Even with some UI flaws and have a chance to crash when you reach 1000 unit mark.But SupCom just feels a bit soulless for me. Mods didn't help all that much which is a pity.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I found that Supreme Commander was such a brilliant game when it was first released i played it over and over again non stop (retail copy then not steam for you trolls who have noticed my game hours are not too great) i loved the commander and how things were built, loved the variety of  ground, air and sea units and loved multiplayer with my mates, however things change.Firstly the fact the game only uses 1 thread of 1 CPU in your system and as a result as the game goes on it piles where your units are where theirs are, shell trajectorys the AI tactics and so on and so forth into 1 thread so it bottlenecks after a period which in turn later on will slow the game down to every game second takes 3 real seconds, you can get the saurion ai patch to fix this somewhat.Unit AI more specifically YOUR unit AI, you spend the game not fighting the enemy but fighting your units as ground units will happily try and shell the tank that is behind a hill that they cant hit due to said hill in the way whilst being cleaned up by enemy tanks that have decided to come around the hill until they have line of sight, air units that just sit on the ground and when an enemy plane comes into range will just pick up and land somewhere else instead of engaging, usually when they take they are then destroyed by any fighters the enemy choose to bring with them.  Sea units are just like tanks and will try and shell things that are out of sight.The commander and anyother building unit can build/capture at range however they like to drive right up to your blueprint or enemy structure before attempting to build or capture, sometimes circling the object until they have found a direction they prefer to face.  Build time is important and building quick is important so any seconds you can save is great but when your commander or engineers fuss about getting into position its very frustrating.Super units are a great thing to build the hardship of your labours, of getting a good economy going to support building such a massive thing, the satisfaction of being able to survive this long to have built such a device and of corse the joy when it is finally complete and the sense of power that runs through you sends a chill up your spine....... but its short lived.  Super units are just as dumb as everything else in your arsenal if not worse i built a monkey lord from the cybran team and sent him off on his merry down the map just as the enemy team (aion) sent up their sacred assualt bot, now the monkey lord has a sweeping red laser which has a greater range than the laser on the assault bot so i though yeeeessss this should not be a problem and promptly told him to attack their assault bot only for him to walk straight by the bot whilst targeting tech 1 tanks of his own choosing stop when he had walked past it out of range of his laser and turn to try and correct this, obviously this was to late cause as soon as he got in range the assault bot had hit him with his laser during the pass and exploded as he stopped then the assault bot promptly cleaned up my base.Obviosly this game has been out a while so this review comes late but its just a warning to any people looking at getting this for the first time be prepared to be frustrated beyond belief at controlling one of the dumbest AI's ever in a strategy game, i cant be bothered to even try and defend this.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												It may just be a Windows 10 issue, but I had nearly no end of problems getting this game to even work at all. I went through dozens of potential fixes and eventually had to literally re-code one of the game files in order to get the thing to work. I probably wouldn't let that tint my overall review of the game if I found it more interesting. This game is like the blunt hammer approach to RTS games where you just hurl units at your opponent until they die and that's pretty much all there is to it. There's no research tree or diplomacy or any of that, it feels like the mechanics are straight out of an RTS game from a decade ago, which I guess a lot of people probably like, but I don't find particularly interesting. I've played a few games with friends and they last about an hour and feel extremely unsatifying. Granted, I was always at the lowest end of the totem pole in terms of score and whatnot, but just nothing really felt engaging about this game. There's not a lot of information given about each of the untis and such and some of the descriptions are vague and unhelpful. The resource section of the game feels like it has potential, but is mostly just an annoyance. There's only two resources in the game and it acts like it is a finely tuned machine where you have to be precise about energy consumption and mass use, but it doesn't give an easy way to monitor these things and keep the balance you need, so more often times than not, my time was spent in the high negatives or high positives and just guessing what units I could build or upgrade without tanking my economy. I will probably play some more with friends, but overall I see zero reason to play this game instead of Age of Empires II, a game where everything is laid out for you and gives you an easy way to manage and monitor your resources and units. As a general rule, I grade all RTS games in comparison to AoE2 and if the game can't beat out a game THAT old, I'm not really interested.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Way back when, I chose the dawn of war games over SupCom. Those DoW games got me into the corresponding tabletop hobby, and I couldnt be happier with the people I've met and all the friends I've made from just buying one little game.A couple days ago, I spotted this on steam and decided to give it a try, see what I would have gotten had I chose this game instead.Before I go on, let me explain that I have always loved RTS games. DoW, AoE, Stronghold, C&C, etc. So when I saw this game and the massively positive reviews for it, I bought it straight away! It looked awesome, whole armies crushing your enemies underfoot, whats not to like?The game worked for me,   only one crash while I was in the tutorial. So no problem there.The problem was, well, the mechanics. I am used to a minimap, when I play againest my competitive friends, the minimap is needed for survival. The tutorial pointed out pretty quick that my screen IS my minimap. Great.Not only did I keep forgetting about it, its also extremely awkward to use. I kept playing without using it, making it seem to me that I was alone, when in fact there was a huge battle going on around me, and I couldnt see it.Secondly, there is a STEEP learning curve. The Controls take way too long to learn and master. I consider myself atleast competent when it comes to RTS's, I can normally figure out the controls in a game or two. With this game? Well, you may notice that I only have TWO hours played on it, and also that I've returned it. Well, thats because these games take HOURS to play. You can't bang out one game in a hour. Heck no. You have to be willing to SIT THERE and WAIT. Wait for your eco to boost up, wait for your buildings to build, wait for your units to be created. Each unit has around a 7-10 second timer. Even the weak units. Yes it has a HUGE pop cap of up to 1000, which is awesome. But for one thing.I can't get any resources. The game wont give you ANYTHING starting out, and resources come in at a TRICKLE. For my first skirmish game after the tutorial, I tried setting it on huge resources or whatever, and it does not have any. You are stuck with the regular resources, which let me tell you, are gone faster then ice placed in the middle of the sahara desert.I had to use CHEATS. CHEATS. To explore the mechanics of the game more fully. I am not one of those people who can sit down for 4-5 hours on ONE game.  This game is for you if you like slow paced afternoon-length games. If you cant invest the time and effort it takes to play this game, dont buy it. I spent two hours with this game. Only played ONE game. And I couldnt even finish it because it got boring using the cheats since it took to long trying to play the game with normal resources and setup.Poor economy, poor unit build time, confusing map interface,  extremely long length game battles without the resources to easily get said long games off the ground effectively, this is a MASSIVE dissapointment to me.Buy if your a HARDCORE RTS player who can spend hours in ONE GAME. If you like RTS' but dont want to invest hours in a single match, or are new to the genre on a whole, or just a casual gamer, SKIP. When I think of the people who might like this game, I think of a old man in his mid 70s.  It requires ALOT of patience. Kudos to anyone who can sit through it, I sure as h*ll cant.Its like you build a beautiful mansion, but then don't install plumbing or power, and only use one room out of the whole mansion.Dissapointed, gave it a chance, glad I chose DoW. Skip if you like anything thats not snail-paced.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This is an RTS I simply couldn't get into. The start-up felt too slow and the war portion didn't live up to my expectations. You are in charge of one robot who can build buildings. From that one robot, you can build resource based buildings and storage compartments as well as unit creation centers. From these buildings, specialized units can be built (air, ground and sea). War units can be build as well as other construction units specialized in their field. A ground construction unit can build an advance ground unit creation center. As for the game play itself,  haven't seen much that impresses me. The units are meek, the attacks seem bland, and the game play just sort of seems boring. I don't feel immersed when I play this game.I wouldn't recommend this game at all.6.0/10.

Posted: November 6, 2015
												Supcom will forever hold a place in my heart, as well as whatever disk space it needs.  Everyone has their "top 5 games of all time" list and this will remain on that list for the rest of my gaming life.  Since I first watched it in development to today, I have never stopped trumpeting just how amazing it really is.  I never miss a chance to try and convince every gamer I know to buy it.  I think I have donated at least five copies to my friends just to have them experiance it.Nearly every RTS before and after have been about just tanks and infantry in small teams... Maybe 100 units at the very most.  Air was usually limited to planes that magically hover in the air and shoot at things until they ran out of ammo, and navy, if present at all, was far less effective than it should really be.  Nuclear weapons and WMD's in Command and Conquer or Starcraft would maybe kill a dozen units and destroy a couple buildings if placed properly.  Nukes in Supcom incinerate everything on the screen, as they absolutly should.Supcom went beyond the level of being a video game and truly pushing the idea of a simulation.  Much like Steel Battalion or high end flight simulators, this game is less a game than it is an experiance.  High APM click-fests (Starcraft) are lauded as the best of the best in the unfairly small RTS genre, but relied far less on tactics and strategy than they did a small group (or in some cases, an individual unit) winning a single battle which mostly judged the outcome of the game.  Supcom recognized that warfare takes a long time, and even the fastest battles are often an attrition match.  The smallest fights often involve dozens of units on each side, with the largest brawls involving hundreds of tanks, artillery support from a secondary line, dozens of aircraft bombing the ground forces and fighting the other aircraft, and fire support from naval units miles away.  This is why Supcom will always stand out as the premier RTS of all time... it is the only one to recognize that there is more to it than a few tanks at a time... Ground air and sea work in conjunction to support eachother.If you have never played this game before, you are truly missing out.  It is something that everyone needs to experiance.  There likely will never be anything else like it.  Even for an 8 year old game, it still looks and sounds amazing.  Nothing else has ever truly given the scale of a warfare simulation like Supcom does.  It is however, punishingly difficult to learn.  There is so much nuance to this game, that people often develop a misconception that the races are too similar when they first learn to play.  It isin't until a deep understanding of the game is reached does the vast differences between the factions becomes realized.  Each side has subtle differences that measure not just the raw stats of the units, but the entire playstyle and even the lore-based philosophy of the faction.  Finally, you can't fanboy this game without mentioning the amazing community of FAF.  It took over running everything when GPG went down.  That so much support exists for a game this old and largely un-mainstream speaks more for it's merits than I ever could.  If you are still unsure of this game being worth checking out, please visit the FAF site at: http://www.faforever.com/

												This is a beast of a game, and used to require a beast of a machine when it was released. Nowadays, however, most PCs can run it on average settings, few can run it on high settings, and even fewer can't run it at all. Posted: July 8, 2014
												Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, likely one of the best purchases I've ever made on Steam, literally. I have nearly 500 in game hours banked into this game and I tell all my gaming friends to try it out. It may not be the most complex or wide scale strategy game out there, but it offers players a fast paced, visually pleasing display of massive battles and base building. It takes a little while to adjust to the drain based resource system. If you're not careful, you can wind up zeroing out on both resource types and your war efforts drop to a crawl and you quickly become cannon fodder.The one thing I absolutely love about this game is the custimization for gameplay. There is no set difficulty, you can pick and choose what kinds of AI you want to play against, whether it be turtles, air, ground, or navy based, or perhaps you prefer a rush style of play, where everyone is hurtling hundreds of puny tanks at each other until someone drops in a massive experimental to slaughter one side or the other. Either way, its the players choice. I also love how easily the game can be modded, I'm not saying its Minecraft where there are thousands of mods out there, but for anyone looking to expand the chaos and scale of the game, drop by the Total Mayhem page on ModdB or perhaps go for the Black Ops mod set.Don't let the age of this game fool you, it may be a few years old, but even the best PC's will eventually lag while trying to handle this game. And yeah, I know, that doesn't sound great, and its not, and it can be annoying, but it gives you a sense of just how massive the game can be.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												Spiritual successor to Total Annihilation. A good RTS if you like big units and bigger explosions and dislike excessive micromanagement. Forged Alliance fixes a lot of things with SupCom, adds a new faction and several units, and generally plays a lot better. It also works fine just a standalone expansion with its own single-player campaign (pretty short, but you can replay via any of the factions with some different in-mission plot details.)EDIT: Recently, I discovered a whole online community at http://www.faforever.com/ that maintains a mod enabling online multiplayer on FAF servers (necessary since GPG shut down their servers) along with new modes, some balancing issues, tons of new maps, and incorporating several other useful mods [notably, Sorian AI for a decent computer player]).

Posted: June 27, 2014
												This is still my favourite RTS game, and its been out since Nov 2007 can you believe! Nothing else comes close it terms of scale, variety of strategies and pure awesomeness (including Planetary Annihilation). When it was released this needed a very high end computer to play nicely, but today the game will look great on most gaming computers. Single player is fun, but multiplayer is where it comes alive. The vanilla version of Supreme Commander was the first game to give you Strategic Zoom (which lets you zoom from a high level view of the entire map right down to individual units with the flick of the mouse wheel) and has a massive variety of units and strategies. You might base your strategy on overwheliming the enemy with low level units, or alternatively sit back and build your economy so you can afford a devestating experimental unit. And of course there's always the nuclear option.While the basic game works fine and there is a multiplayer lobby inegrated with steam for the steam version you really want to download Forged Alliance Forever. This is a community built multiplayer lobby, which has matchmaking, map and replay vaults, popular mods etc, and has helped massively extend the life of the game.Nuclear launch detected...

												This is the best game I have ever played, the capaign is short but fun however multiplayer is where the magic happens - as GPG no longer exists you MUST get FAF http://www.faforever.com/ - a community mulitplayer lobby client for Forged Alliance, it features matchmaking, ladder matches, automatic downloading of new mods/maps for any games you join not to mention improvements to the game balances and also core features themselve (12 player multiplayer!)The game itself is for me is the pinicle of real-time strategy gaming, games support 1000s of units, tank shells, missiles, flak is all simulated so cunning micro management of your units can actually let you dodge enemy fire (lesser games simlify this to a game of scissors, paper, stone meaning if you are outnumbered you usually have to watch them die or jab special hot keys for each unit like a maniac)Be warned however to get into multiplayer you will have to overcome a steep learning curve, however there are plenty of noob friendly hosts on FAF and many Youtube videos which can show you the basics of build orders and managing your economy.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Spiritual succesor to Total Annihilatoin they said. Well I agree but there are a couple of things that still make the original TA a better game. For starters SupCom takes a LONG time to get a base up and running at maximum efficiency with multiple factories churning out tanks and bots, and the problem is that the AI immediately begins attacking you fom the start so unless you repel the first rush properly and you are able to repel each subsequent attack on your position, because by the time you have dealt with the first the second is often already on the way, then you are screwed. The maps are much larger which makes for more epic combat and I must say this is a good thing. You can play with more than 4 players on one map as opposed to TA and that is also good. There are three tech levels instead of two and the ability to customize your commander unit which is also pretty cool but beware that upgrading takes much MUCH more ressources, easily exponential amounts which means if your ressources infrastructures are not ready your facotories will simply stop producing. This is what I had the most trouble with in this game whereas in TA I always got the upper hand on the ressource situation I have a very difficult time maintaining my production in this game because of how expensive good units are. Producing masses of tech one level units is simplky not worht it because a tech two unit can easily outmatch upwards of a dozen tech one units and so on for a tech three unit. Furthermore on the ressource issue, the AI methodically targets your ressource infrastucture before even targetting defensive turrets at times which simply adds to the trouble of collecting enough ressources to maintain production. This is not a complaint in itself just somkething that adds to my troubles with the game.All in all this game is very good though if you liked TA just don't expect it to be a revamped reworked version of the 1997 classic because this game has a flavour all of its own. Epic battles await and Nukes are awesome in this game.cheers

Posted: August 1, 2014
												In my opinion, Forged Alliance can only be described as one of the best Real-Time RTS games of its type. Despite its age it still looks modern with high graphics settings and the addition of a 4th race to the game expands the gameplay possibility compared to the original. However the best thing about this game is the loyal community that continue support of the game with new updates and balance changes through the Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) Lobby after support for the game ceased. FAF provides the essential multiplayer this game absolutly thrives on, the game is still very competitive through the multiplayer and therefore I can also recommend Forged Alliance to seasoned veterans of the RTS genre. The game has quite a steep learning curve though and the fact that there can be 1000s of units on the battlefield means that the game can be laggy unless you have a good computer. Despite this, I think it is a brilliant title that is definitly worth your time if you have any interest whatsoever in the genre, especially as this part of the genre has very little competition.

Posted: October 15, 2013
												A bittersweet standalone expansion to Supreme Commander that polishes the user experience to be smoother than before. The complexity and depth of this strategy game can have fans playing for years without ever coming close to mastering it, but it lacks a worthy multiplayer community to take advantage of it. The visuals still seem acceptable despite being over 5 years old and the soundscape is far better than that of the sequel, but oddly enough, it still is very demanding as far as CPU power spec goes, favoring modern desktop Intel processors (ex. Core i5 2500k/3570k), much more than AMDs offerings. For a game with four diverse factions and multiple theaters of war (land/hover, aircraft/low orbit/long range missiles, naval/amphib, etc.), this game has enough strategic variety to produce some truly memorable battles, but could be much better. The campaign treats you to a brief sci-fi story of humanity facing extinction by the hands of aliens, but having no time limit makes it a bit easy if you just build up before progressing to the next stage. The AI in skirmish mode is no challenge once its pattern is figured out, or too hard if you choose to play the cheating "AIx". Fortunately, this game is mod friendly and many mods have been released that further enhance and refresh the game experience, such as BlackOps Unleashed. A separate community driven multiplayer lobby, FA Forever, has emerged and is maturing to help keep the fire in this game lit for strategy gamers worldwide to enjoy. Gamers who have enjoyed this or Total Annihilation years ago may likely find it is worth getting [back] into this for some semi-competitive multiplayer action.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												I recently picked this up after playing alot of Planetary Annihilation. I used to play this and Supreme Commander back when they were first released, years ago. I hadnt touched this game in several years and its been really fun to play it on a system that handles it in high performance.In some ways PA is a harder game to play than this and in others this game is as RTS hard mode as it gets. The economy can be very difficult to learn and hold steady. Keep at it though because once you crack the nut of resource mangment you start playing a game that is wholey unique. The maps are huge and the unit count is massive. This game is slower than PA but in a good way. Long games are beautiful to behold; armies of tanks, bots and mobile artillary duke it out while waves and waves of planes fight in the air. Huge artillary batteries and strategic missle launchers lay waste to the map and it always ends up looking like a metal waste land when all the wreckage is strewn across the map. If you enjoy very strategic thinking and RTS games I highly recommend this game. If your a casual or new RTS player, play this with caution, it may be overwhelming.

												A must-have for every serious gamer out there, specially those who are fascinated by fast-paced and spectacular RTS games. It is based of course on the amazing in its own rights "Supreme Commander" (and that in turn on the even older classic gem labeled "Total Annihilation"), but expands it with a whole new race, new units and game fixes that balance many of its predecessor's features. Not only does it fulfill its RTS expectations but, imho, it expands and sets a new paradigm for the whole genre. Nuclear blasts, incredible massive experimental units of formidable power, shielding and cloaking abilities, are just a few of the things expected in the game. If you are in for an addictive gameplay and an enthusiastic community - even after all these years - that supports the game, then you should go ahead try it.

Posted: January 1, 2016
Good thingsI have spent hundreds of hours playing this game and it is really worth its price.  It is a newer version of Total Annihilation. The game is quite innovative and has features not seen before (or very rare) in other RTS games: you can zoom out the main view so that you see the entire map you can split the main view into two hence being able to see to different areas of the map, each of the views has full zoom support so you can use one of them as a global map (i.e. have it always zoomed out) on top of that, there is also a minimap, which is just another view with all the same features (e.g. you can zoom in), furthemore you can place it anywhere you want or switch it off support for multi-display computers, so you can have a "minimap" of the size of your secondary display device you can queue and loop factories' production you can queue buildings to be built by constructors in your factories, you can set not only a rally point but the entire path of tasks, e.g. newly constructed robot will go to the transport ship that will transport it closer to enemy base and then it will patrol the area. The transport ship automatically comes back to the pickup point for new robots you can select multiple buildings and save them as a schematic so the next time you can order the construction of all of them with single click the resource management is the most interesting part - instead of having just stored resources you have storage and production. You can start a construction even if you don't have enough resources stored. A few examples how it works: the building costs 1500 metal, you have +30 metal per second and your constructor uses 15 metal per second - it will take 100 seconds you finish construction you add another constructor so together they use 30 metal per second - your metal production drops to 0 and the building will be constructed in 50 seconds you have 3 constructors building two such buildings at the same time, with storage empty you train to use 45 metal per second while your production is only 30. This means that each constructor will be using only 10 metal per second instead of 15 they use normally. So the building with two constructors assigned will be finished in 1500/20 = 75 seconds, by that time the second building with one constructor assigned will have only 75 * 10 = 750 metal used meaning it's 50% complete you can order your constructors to support one or many buildings so they will automatically repair them or rebuild destroyed onesBad thingsThe game has one huge disadvantage with no work around (there are mods which slightly improve it). On large maps with large unit limits (e.g. 1000) the AI creates so many units that it cannot handle it, which slows the game down (there are no FPS issues, but 10 second in reality is 1 second in game). There are no issues in the campaign, multiplayer and on smaller maps.Other notes it is worth playing Supreme Commander's campaign before you get used to new units added in this stand-alone expansion the best features of this game listed above have been removed in Supreme Commander 2, making it a classic RTS which has nothing to do with Supreme Commander, Forged Alliance or Total Annihilation

Posted: February 23, 2014
												My favorite RTS of all time. More massive in scale than anything I have ever seen, overwhelmed every CPU when it was released in 2007 (due to accuracy in simulation unlike any other RTS), now runs OK on newer generation CPUs.A really different RTS, no research tree, all units are available from the start, very complex and challenging resource system (but a very fair one). Tons of units and focus on strategy, not tactics (like most other RTS that are much smaller scale and deal with mere 40 to 80 units)Uses second monitor as a map screen, game maps range from 5 to 5 km squared to 80 by 80 km huge spaces.This game has a realistic balance between offensive units and defensive units: i.e. unlike most other RTSes, you can actually defend a position with ground based defenses.Contains 4 Tech levels: Tech 1 to 3, plus experimentals, which are super huge units that are more powerful than any other units and take a long time to build. This game is NOT for casual gamers, it takes dedication and learning to handle it. But once you do, it is incredible fun, especially against other human players (AI is boring) Game playtimes range from 10 minutes (rare) to 2 hours. An average interesting game is probably 30 to 50 mins. Like in real war, a lot of time is spend building your army and preparing an assault, it is not focused on mindless nonstop fighting.

												You might say: “Why should I get this game, instead of planetary annihilations?”Well, you should get this game because of how fun it is to play alone, or with friends! Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance redefined the RTS genre, letting you build an army of thousands of units ranging from submersible aircraft carriers to experimental nuclear missile launchers.If you do get this game, then use the Forged Alliance Forever launcher (or FAF, you can find it on google), it fixes a lot of bugs and the community over there is really active!Note: If this game will run on pretty much any decent CPU, but it can only use one core (or thread)! Posted: March 23, 2013
												Absolutely love this game. I have played it for years prior to getting it on Steam. Anyway, just here to let people know that if you're a die hard fan like me, you should get the BlackOps Mods. You can always just turn them off in game if you don't like them, but I doubt that will be the case. They are: BlackOpsACUs, BlackOpsEXUnits, BlackOpsNavalBalance, BlackOpsUnleashed. - These Mods are extrmemely well done, to the extent of not even being able to tell where the original game ends, and these Mods begin. Highlights include new units in every tech level which alter play strategies, and new experimentals which balance the races. About half of the new experientals are superior to the orginal games experimentals. My favorite addition though is what they did to the ACUs. Through a massive restructure, you can upgrade commanders through each tech level up to experimental level. Ever want your ACU to stand toe to toe with a colossus? Well, now you can. I would also recommend getting Sorian_AI_Mod_2.1.2. - This almost doubles the amount of AI to choose from when selecting which AI to fight against in skirmish or multiplayer missions, and at its peak, adds a level of difficulty far superior to the original game, guaranteed to challenge even the most veteran players.

Posted: September 12, 2015
												Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is the type of Real Time Strategy game that plays well with old-school strategy gamers, requiring players to spend hours of sweat, blood, and tears before they can deploy their fleets of lumbering robots against their foe. SC:FA has great tactical depth and fetches a fair amount of complex resource-management and army organization, yet bears enough sheer RTS joy to appease both more casual and hard-core RTS gamers alike. With SC:FA’s blend of generic alien vs man sci-fi action thrown in with the politics of the previous game’s 3 human factions, the game also concocts a pretty enjoyable storyline to campaign with. The best way, I feel, to evaluate the game is to compare it to the more modern successor, Supreme Commander 2. SC2 has all the trappings of a modern RTS sci-fi product; flying, creeping, and hovering robots of all shapes and sizes zipping around a well sculpted battlefield, brightly colored lasers and missiles flying about under the player’s direction. Being of the same company and storyline, each game uses the same two resources and the same style of base building (with the usage of shields, turrets, and factories that produce everything from small tanks to submarine-aircraft carriers). The storyline of SC2 isn’t as important nor as interesting, but what makes both games stand out as frontrunners of the two different RTS genres is the differing styles of tactical gameplay and resource gathering.Instead of varying sizes of landmasses, such as in SC:FA in which it can take twenty minutes for fuel-thirsty aircraft to reach the end of the map, SC2 possesses much smaller maps, where even the slowest units take no more than five minutes to reach point B. In terms of tactical management, aircrafts of all factions in SC:FA need refueled at specialized staging facilities. This isn’t relevant in SC2, with aircraft being able to fly over targets and friendly bases indefinitely. Also, a notable difference rests in the building of what is known in both games as “experimental units” or just unique units that are the culmination of your particular faction’s military genius (for example, the United Earth Federation’s Fatboy landship). The Fatboy unit in SC:FA can cross over water, possesses shields and anti-aircraft capabilities, and has very powerful guns, all at the cost of twenty minutes of time. However, in SC2, the Fatboy unit only wields the large guns, with all other abilities missing, giving the unit a much cheaper cost at a three minute production rate. These examples serve to set apart the two different RTS styles; the newer version represents how tactical depth and patience have been replaced by spectacle and awe.To conclude, if you’re the type of gamer that likes to spend loads of time setting the pieces up in order to get to the nuclear explosions, then this is the game for you. (Disclamer-I bought the steam version to replace a lost disc version I used to have. So more like 10 hours on record)

Posted: July 7, 2015
												Hello!Ahhhh, Supreme Commander, specifically Forged Alliance. I grew up on several games, this being one of them. It is definitely one of the greatest RTS’s I have ever seen. Basically, there are two ways one can play this game, rushing or turtling. But when you add that a wide variety of maps, factions, units, tech trees, and complex AI’s that break your face in with ARMIES UPON ARMIES OF T1 TANKS!?!? It gets pretty darn fun. Graphics are amazing for a game released in 2007, the units mix well with the terrain, and the overlay is perfect. Mechanics are pretty perfect, everything is pretty balanced, and there are plenty of options for stuff in the custom lobby.Price is perfect, the expansion Forged Alliance is a must get, and it is the TRUE sequel to SupCom, not SupCom 2 made by Square Enix.A great recommendation, the learning curve may be a slight bit steep, but this game is a must-have for anybody starting an adventure into RTS Games.~Wolfy

Posted: July 18, 2015
												This is one of the best RTS games as of 2015. When it launched it was an incredible resource hog as it suggested 2 monitors and required a great deal more processing power than most people had. It is a beautiful game overall and the balance is quite good. The ability to make massive super weapons is a real joy because they are quite powerful but they take a long time to build and can be a gamble if the enemy blows them up before they are finished.This game is oldschool in the sense that it doesn't have cheating AI that always knows exactly what you're doing. It will build the tech 3 radar that has a massive detection range... but that's a structure you can build as well. (you can always blow it up or take out his power to turn it off). This game has a slight degree of technicality with your base setup (the wiki can explain it very quickly with a picture). Long story short you can put power plants next to factories and each will reduce the cost of things you build in the factories. The other game resource, mass, will also reduce building costs if you build a factory on top of a mass extractor (often called a mex). The danger with this is that a tight network of touching/linked buildings is more effecient but it is much easier to destroy because power plants are volitile,The bad news is that the AI can't really compete very well on water maps. The AI is also somewhat weak to turtle strategies involving large defensive structure batteries. However one of the interesting aspects of this game is that you kinda need to learn which thing to build to counter what your opponent is building. Did I mention that anything you send at the enemy's base that gets destroyed can have the mass reclaimed by the enemy?One more bit of bad news is that I don't think a lot of people play so you'll probably be playing against the AI. That being said the AI is a good opponent. There is a built in "cheater" option if you want to play against a crazy tough AI opponent who will always be 1-2 steps ahead of you. This is a really good game and the first time you see a nuclear missile hit the enemy base you will really be in for a treat. If you hear the words strategic launch detected and don't have countermeasures built you'll be in trouble.This is one of those games you can play for hundreds of hours and never feel like you're still playing to get your money's worth.

Chrise Taylor was telling a whole bunch of lies when in an interview he once said that this game was future proof, it does not use all cpu cores correctly, in fact it only uses one core of my i7 4790k effectively, thats ok when playing on my computer in campaign mode, but when it comes to playing multiplayer games, this is where this otherwise brilliant game comes tumbling to a halt. this games begins to slow down within half an hour of playing on a 20 x 20 map with 6 players and a unit count of 1,000, so big eppic games are out the window in reality, I do recoment this game for anyone who loves rts games, mainly for its single player mode and not the Multiplayer.

Posted: June 9, 2015
												This is a super awesome RTS. The economy is really difficult to get a handle on, but once you get used to it, start to see how it all fits together, and then start implementing those newfound skills, it feels immensely rewarding. It also blows balls when a bomber takes out one power generator that's connected to an entire grid of power generators and your entire base goes black, just before a different enemy sends in an experimental unit to wreak havok. But those are also the kind of moments in the game that makes it special. There's something oddly amazing about playing defense, but not so much in terms of using units, but rather resource management to make sure your sheild generators don't drop. It feels like a strangely realistic version of over the top sci-fi warfare. On the one hand, you can just spam light units like the Ruskies, or you can focus on developing base defense and researching up to higher-tech units. The crazy thing is that this game doesn't really focus on a "rock-papers-scissors" balancing form, as even if one player has tons of low level units, if an opposing player brings in two experimentals, the other player is essentially screwed. The scale of the maps is big enough for large-scale strategies, and the games are long enough to actually develop them over time. It's just... It's unique, and I mean that in a good way.

Posted: April 20, 2015
												An Awesome game, having played the first game, i wasn't surprised as much by the lack of a learning curve. I just jumped in, got to building and blew the enemy away. And by building i mean i took my time, i built formidable bases. Then built me an army and or fleet, to take the first objective, but before taking that i built more armies and or fleets, so i had some left over for when the map expanded. You do not want to get caught without those forces when the final and biggest enemy base finally appears on your map. You must take your time and you must fortify your whole base, lack of proper defenses will have the enemy dropship troops onto your doorstep and blow your infra structure to smithereens. Rushing will lead to you being overwhelmed by the forces the enemy had stockpiled. You'll know what i mean once 4 experimentals are marching towards your base and you don't have anything to stop them with. The story isn't much, just a little something to hang the action onto, but it's okay.  Visiually it does what is neccesary, allowing vast armies to clash and lovely explosions to cover the field from left to right. I get a blast from seeing nukes going off over the enemies productions centers. Special mention should be made of the AI, while not genius level. It did target my radar early on so its attacks would  be more of a surprise, line of sight then being the criteria for a lot of units to shoot despite their range. And it took particular offense to my building the experimental building that would have ended my economic needs. It got bombed conventionally twice as i was building it and actually launched a nuke at it for attempt number three. For me, the whole base building and taking my time is what makes, RTS so much fun. Spending two hours a mission is nothing. (for me anyway)

Posted: May 22, 2015
												If I could, I would give this game 3 thumbs up!<<<PLAY-TIME HOUR COUNT>>>I know Steam says I have twenty-two minutes play-time but that's a bit shy of the actual number. I bought this game retail when it first came out many years ago and have played so many hours I've lost track. With many years of playing, I would estimate my hour count in the thousands. I still use my retail copy so have no real need to use the Steam version. The only reason I installed it was because Steam says I need to play five minutes before I can review.  Anyway, on to what you came here for...the review, enjoy :).<<<OVERVIEW>>>Chris Taylor knew what he was doing on this one (unlike Supreme Commander 2 :P). It was way ahead of its time in graphics. It excels in the use of varied factions and the diversity of their units. No two games are the same; you can play a game with the same exact settings and have a completely different outcome.<<<VISUALS>>>You may think that because this game is old is lacks in good graphics or up-to-date features. I can assure you this is not the case. This game rests safely in my top five strategy games of all time even to this day. The graphics are still quite stunning due to the fact that it was very resource-heavy when it came out. They didn't skimp on models, textures and animations.<<<FEATURES>>>The tactical features are second-to-none.> For example, the use of groups include the ability to move in formation and move-fire.> You can save several camera positions and recall/alter/delete them at will for quick camera movement across even very large maps.> You can use both split screen and dual monitors in any combination.> The ability to queue up builds and save templates makes it very easy to setup your base ahead of time and go fight/build/scout somewhere else on the map while it's getting built.> You can name landmarks and units for easy identification even at a distance.> There are several different ping command types which your AI allies will respond to.There are many different features and key/mouse combos, so many in fact, that after over twelve years of playing, I'm still finding a new one now and then.<<<LEARNING THE GAME>>>Be Warned!This is not a game for n00bs. If you think you're gonna walk in and pwn because you've played StarCraft, you've got another think coming. It's light years ahead of kiddie games like that. While you should be efficient in your building, victory has nothing to do with Clicks Per Minute. SupCom:FA is for serious strategy/tactic junkies. The sheer map size and unit/faction variation makes weeding out the click-kiddies from actual strategists/tacticians a very simple task. A good rule of thumb is, if you don't have the ability and patience to play chess, you probably won't like this game.This game has a fairly steep learning curve; if, for nothing else, for efficiency in shortcut-key/key-combo features.It is not a typical triad-based unit type game either. The factions are given different strengths and weaknesses and the player will have to play to those strengths and take advantage of his opponent's faction's weaknesses. The factions are intentionally unbalanced to create a genuine variation in games, play-styles, over-all strategy and tactics.<<<MODDING>>>While you can enjoy this game vanilla, I would highly recommend modding it. There are many mods out there for it and you would benefit from many of them. You don't have to learn to mod if you don't want to, just install the existing ones you want. "Forged Alliance Forever" is a great group dedicated to keeping this game alive. There are many resources available for you with a quick google search. All mods are written in LUA and the base unit script archives can be treated as zips if you want to do some modding yourself. There are wikis out there to help you if you're up for it. The details you can adjust are granular going all the way to salvo size, reload rates and gun barrel turn radius to name only a few. Even game settings and UI can be modded.NOTE: be sure, if you're playing with mods, that whoever you play with has the exact same files or the game will desync. UI mods don't count, you can use as many of these as you like without anyone else needing them.<<<FINAL NOTES>>>If you mod this properly, you can enjoy thousands of hours of fun; I know I have and still do :D. Give it a try, you won't regret it.

Posted: June 24, 2015
												There are other RTS games that are closer to my heart and that I've had more fun with, but I have to admit that this is probably the best RTS ever made, and still one of the best PvP RTS games to play in 2015 if you install the 3rd party FAF (Forged Alliance Forever) client (requires valid steam or cd copy).Epic pretty much sums up this game, as you will be amazed by the great designs (looks better than not only all games from the same time period, but most RTS games that were released the next 10 years as well), massive battles, more than enough units and awesome hero (commander) mechanics that make this game playable in two or three completely different ways. The economy system is also slightly different than other games, and challenges you a lot more to play as well as you can, but is also very forgiving if you design it to be (with minimal economic loss).As long as you play the tutorial it's not very hard getting into the basics of the game, but after a douzen games there might be some things you still haven't figured out and won't either for the next 100 games. Look around, try every button and you will find this game has a lot of good mechanics and features you don't see in a lot of games.The game engine, however, is slightly limited and if you set the total unit cap too high in games with more than 3-4 players it will slow down. 75%, 50% or even 20% game speed is common for games of decent size. There's fewer people who have an issue with this than people who don't, but it's worth keeping in mind when you buy the game. To play with 3000 units on the same map you will have to make compromises.The story is great though, and combined with a multiplayer that will have you playing every map twice or more it would have been worth buying for many times more than what it costs on Steam on full price.If you have ever enjoyed any RTS game, you HAVE TO buy this game!

												The best RTS on the block. Massive battles with units ranging from tiny robots to huge battle-changing experimental robots that cut giant swaths of destruction in their path. Units are balanced against each other but not in a 'rock/paper/scissors' fashion but tiered. Upper tier units can be defeated by superior numbers but lower tier units pack less of a punch. The interface is also fantastic, allowing you to program long strings of build commands, attack commands, coordinated attacks, patrol commands, etc... You can even save good build plans you like so you can use them again in later games. Forged Alliance added new units and while it's an expansion, it DOES NOT REQUIRE SUPREME COMMANDER. It will run on its own containing everything in Supreme Commander. And don't bother with Supreme Commander 2. We don't speak of its heretical existence. SupCom:FA is the alpha and the omega. Long live Total Annihilation!

												Absolutely love this game. I have played it for years prior to getting it on Steam. Anyway, just here to let people know that if you're a die hard fan like me, you should get the BlackOps Mods. You can always just turn them off in game if you don't like them, but I doubt that will be the case. They are: BlackOpsACUs, BlackOpsEXUnits, BlackOpsNavalBalance, BlackOpsUnleashed. - These Mods are extrmemely well done, to the extent of not even being able to tell where the original game ends, and these Mods begin. Highlights include new units in every tech level which alter play strategies, and new experimentals which balance the races. About half of the new experientals are superior to the orginal games experimentals. My favorite addition though is what they did to the ACUs. Through a massive restructure, you can upgrade commanders through each tech level up to experimental level. Ever want your ACU to stand toe to toe with a colossus? Well, now you can. I would also recommend getting Sorian_AI_Mod_2.1.2. - This almost doubles the amount of AI to choose from when selecting which AI to fight against in skirmish or multiplayer missions, and at its peak, adds a level of difficulty far superior to the original game, guaranteed to challenge even the most veteran players.

Posted: September 12, 2015
												Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is the type of Real Time Strategy game that plays well with old-school strategy gamers, requiring players to spend hours of sweat, blood, and tears before they can deploy their fleets of lumbering robots against their foe. SC:FA has great tactical depth and fetches a fair amount of complex resource-management and army organization, yet bears enough sheer RTS joy to appease both more casual and hard-core RTS gamers alike. With SC:FA’s blend of generic alien vs man sci-fi action thrown in with the politics of the previous game’s 3 human factions, the game also concocts a pretty enjoyable storyline to campaign with. The best way, I feel, to evaluate the game is to compare it to the more modern successor, Supreme Commander 2. SC2 has all the trappings of a modern RTS sci-fi product; flying, creeping, and hovering robots of all shapes and sizes zipping around a well sculpted battlefield, brightly colored lasers and missiles flying about under the player’s direction. Being of the same company and storyline, each game uses the same two resources and the same style of base building (with the usage of shields, turrets, and factories that produce everything from small tanks to submarine-aircraft carriers). The storyline of SC2 isn’t as important nor as interesting, but what makes both games stand out as frontrunners of the two different RTS genres is the differing styles of tactical gameplay and resource gathering.Instead of varying sizes of landmasses, such as in SC:FA in which it can take twenty minutes for fuel-thirsty aircraft to reach the end of the map, SC2 possesses much smaller maps, where even the slowest units take no more than five minutes to reach point B. In terms of tactical management, aircrafts of all factions in SC:FA need refueled at specialized staging facilities. This isn’t relevant in SC2, with aircraft being able to fly over targets and friendly bases indefinitely. Also, a notable difference rests in the building of what is known in both games as “experimental units” or just unique units that are the culmination of your particular faction’s military genius (for example, the United Earth Federation’s Fatboy landship). The Fatboy unit in SC:FA can cross over water, possesses shields and anti-aircraft capabilities, and has very powerful guns, all at the cost of twenty minutes of time. However, in SC2, the Fatboy unit only wields the large guns, with all other abilities missing, giving the unit a much cheaper cost at a three minute production rate. These examples serve to set apart the two different RTS styles; the newer version represents how tactical depth and patience have been replaced by spectacle and awe.To conclude, if you’re the type of gamer that likes to spend loads of time setting the pieces up in order to get to the nuclear explosions, then this is the game for you. (Disclamer-I bought the steam version to replace a lost disc version I used to have. So more like 10 hours on record)

Posted: September 19, 2015
												If you are deciding between PA or the new PA: TITANS and this. BUY THIS GAME NOW WITHOUT HESITATION! JUST, TRUST ME! I know on Steam it says I only have a few hours, well that's because I only recently rebought the game through Steam. I have owned the game in the box since 2006, back when it was worth $100 retail, and played countless hours on both Supreme Commander and the Forged Alliance standalone.Supreme Commander and Supereme Commander: Forged Alliance are the games that inspired PA, and unlike PA, Supreme Commander has enthralling stories and campaigns. And it most importantly, has personality. PA is lifeless and has 1 shared faction across all players. Supreme Commander Forged Alliance has 4 factions, each unique and screaming personality and lore. With their own advantages and disadvantages.UEF is the all around balanced faction, it posses no real advantages over the other factions. But has no real disadvatnages on that note either.Cybran Nation is a strong early, weak middle and strong again late game faction (early being as far as 30 minutes in depending on gamemode, map and players). They have superior land tech and some of the cheapest units in the game. They output allot of damage at the expense of low health across all their units.Aeon Illuminate is a weak early, OK middle and Extreme late game faction. Aeon Illuminate posses the most powerful experimentals (note: experimentals are no longer game winners in Forged Alliance, they are just game changers.) Although their units take a very long to produce they pay off with extreme damage and high health.Seraphim was added in the Forged Alliance standalone, they are a mix of the UEF and Aeon Illuminate, in my opinion. They have no real advantage or disadvantage, they just added new life to the game. They do have extremely powerful and expensive experimentals, and have the one true game ending experimental left, the experimental nuke. The Seripham have effective land and air experientals too, but the experiemental nuke is on the list of the most feared experimentals in the game.Keep in mind, each faction has it's own "game ending" experimental, but they are always super expensive. And can take upwards of 40 minutes real time to complete if you're efficent and have the builders to assist.Machanics: 10/10Story: 10/10Personality: 10/10Multiplayer: 5/10 - It works, but you need a program called "game ranger". When the game was released it was too CPU/Network expensive to do anything but LAN at the time.Multiplayer with Game Ranger: 10/10total: 45/50BUY IT!

Posted: November 7, 2015
												Dont look at this 2h game time. I've spent a lot in this game before i bought it on Steam.For me this is the best RTS I've ever played. The reasons for this are:- Epic battles. Thousands of units of different size and shape on land, water and in the air. Battle between huge armies look really massive and epic.- Great economy model. Buildings receive different bonuses from resource buildings nearby, encouraging you to plan your base's architecture. The game also has build/uprade assistance from constructors and reclamation.- Micro doesnt play a major role, unlike in Starcrafts and other popular RTS tiles, where the winner is the one who does more clicks per second.- Fractions seem alike a the first glance, but the small differences in unit's capabilities, like being amphibious, or having a shield, can become a huge advantage if used properly.- Epic experimental units, capable of defeating small armies alone. They are all different and unique.- Many small things that make the game comfortable, like building queues/plans, possible building distribution between factories, automated unit transportation from assembly point to te battlefield and many others.The only reason this game is a little forgotten is it's complexity. To bad it became a disadvantage in modern gaming world.

Posted: November 6, 2015
												Supcom will forever hold a place in my heart, as well as whatever disk space it needs.  Everyone has their "top 5 games of all time" list and this will remain on that list for the rest of my gaming life.  Since I first watched it in development to today, I have never stopped trumpeting just how amazing it really is.  I never miss a chance to try and convince every gamer I know to buy it.  I think I have donated at least five copies to my friends just to have them experiance it.Nearly every RTS before and after have been about just tanks and infantry in small teams... Maybe 100 units at the very most.  Air was usually limited to planes that magically hover in the air and shoot at things until they ran out of ammo, and navy, if present at all, was far less effective than it should really be.  Nuclear weapons and WMD's in Command and Conquer or Starcraft would maybe kill a dozen units and destroy a couple buildings if placed properly.  Nukes in Supcom incinerate everything on the screen, as they absolutly should.Supcom went beyond the level of being a video game and truly pushing the idea of a simulation.  Much like Steel Battalion or high end flight simulators, this game is less a game than it is an experiance.  High APM click-fests (Starcraft) are lauded as the best of the best in the unfairly small RTS genre, but relied far less on tactics and strategy than they did a small group (or in some cases, an individual unit) winning a single battle which mostly judged the outcome of the game.  Supcom recognized that warfare takes a long time, and even the fastest battles are often an attrition match.  The smallest fights often involve dozens of units on each side, with the largest brawls involving hundreds of tanks, artillery support from a secondary line, dozens of aircraft bombing the ground forces and fighting the other aircraft, and fire support from naval units miles away.  This is why Supcom will always stand out as the premier RTS of all time... it is the only one to recognize that there is more to it than a few tanks at a time... Ground air and sea work in conjunction to support eachother.If you have never played this game before, you are truly missing out.  It is something that everyone needs to experiance.  There likely will never be anything else like it.  Even for an 8 year old game, it still looks and sounds amazing.  Nothing else has ever truly given the scale of a warfare simulation like Supcom does.  It is however, punishingly difficult to learn.  There is so much nuance to this game, that people often develop a misconception that the races are too similar when they first learn to play.  It isin't until a deep understanding of the game is reached does the vast differences between the factions becomes realized.  Each side has subtle differences that measure not just the raw stats of the units, but the entire playstyle and even the lore-based philosophy of the faction.  Finally, you can't fanboy this game without mentioning the amazing community of FAF.  It took over running everything when GPG went down.  That so much support exists for a game this old and largely un-mainstream speaks more for it's merits than I ever could.  If you are still unsure of this game being worth checking out, please visit the FAF site at: http://www.faforever.com/

Posted: October 8, 2014
												After you buy this game, (which if you haven't already, what's taking you so long) head over to faforever.com, a community lobby built by the SupCom community. It is ~10,000 members strong, with a competition ladder, up to 6v6 custom matches, a dozen+ mods, galactic war, the campaigns of SupCom and Forged Alliance redone to allow up to 4 player co-op, and more. It's free and adds far more to this game than any other RTS on the market.Hands down the best RTS game available. This game really does things right by focusing on the obliteration of your opponents through sheer force of strength and easy economy management. Don't like the tediousness of micro-managing your economy and just want to throw hundreds of units constantly at each other? Are you annoyed that you have to wait until you have resources stockpiled before you can build units? Want to build massive units to wipe your enemies off the face of the earth? Do you enjoy being able to specialize in either land, air, or naval units, or use combinations of each? This game is what you're looking for. Now the only question is, what are you waiting for?

Posted: May 24, 2015
												A complete masterpiece, and the mark of one of the greatest RTS games ever created. If you know your history then you are aware that the RTS genre was very popular from the late 90's to mid 2000's, this is also the time slot when some of the best games in the genre were made, like age of empires 2 and company of heroes. However when it comes to destroying other factions on a massive scale no other game even comes close. With the original supreme commander being good, but not great, and the sequal being a total cash grab by square, this game remains the best in the series and I only wish that creative assembly the strategy giant, would buy the rights to a third game. Maybe then the franchise would get the treatment that it truly deserves.

Posted: April 25, 2015
												This game was on my radar when supreme commander was still in beta.  I played "total annillation" back in the day, which this game is based off of.  Needless to say I couldn't wait. When this game came out in 2007 you couldn't find or build a computer that could play a game on max units/max map size.  This has kept the game very relevent even 8 years later. The most epic strategy game every made. Its just great. The AI leaves some to be desired. A single cheating AI stomps me most times, and the next step down from that I can kill like three AI's at once. So play against humans if you can. "FA forever" is a mod that you allows you to play mulitplayer with a  (i believe) wider community than those who play on steam servers.ALSO. If you have anything the does something tricky with your graphics settings, completely uninstall it or the game wont run at all in windows 8/8.1.. example: Virtu MVP. If you still have problems there are custom video setting ini files you can download that will help you get the game going.Furthermore, supreme commander 2 is complete garbage compared to this game.. unless you are a small child or elderly person that can't handle the complexity. lol.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												In my opinion, Forged Alliance can only be described as one of the best Real-Time RTS games of its type. Despite its age it still looks modern with high graphics settings and the addition of a 4th race to the game expands the gameplay possibility compared to the original. However the best thing about this game is the loyal community that continue support of the game with new updates and balance changes through the Forged Alliance Forever (FAF) Lobby after support for the game ceased. FAF provides the essential multiplayer this game absolutly thrives on, the game is still very competitive through the multiplayer and therefore I can also recommend Forged Alliance to seasoned veterans of the RTS genre. The game has quite a steep learning curve though and the fact that there can be 1000s of units on the battlefield means that the game can be laggy unless you have a good computer. Despite this, I think it is a brilliant title that is definitly worth your time if you have any interest whatsoever in the genre, especially as this part of the genre has very little competition.

Posted: June 9, 2015
												This is a super awesome RTS. The economy is really difficult to get a handle on, but once you get used to it, start to see how it all fits together, and then start implementing those newfound skills, it feels immensely rewarding. It also blows balls when a bomber takes out one power generator that's connected to an entire grid of power generators and your entire base goes black, just before a different enemy sends in an experimental unit to wreak havok. But those are also the kind of moments in the game that makes it special. There's something oddly amazing about playing defense, but not so much in terms of using units, but rather resource management to make sure your sheild generators don't drop. It feels like a strangely realistic version of over the top sci-fi warfare. On the one hand, you can just spam light units like the Ruskies, or you can focus on developing base defense and researching up to higher-tech units. The crazy thing is that this game doesn't really focus on a "rock-papers-scissors" balancing form, as even if one player has tons of low level units, if an opposing player brings in two experimentals, the other player is essentially screwed. The scale of the maps is big enough for large-scale strategies, and the games are long enough to actually develop them over time. It's just... It's unique, and I mean that in a good way.
